review_title: Great People Choking on Beurocracy & Funding Cuts
pros: The University provides excellent health insurance - even to graduate students above a certain number of hours. Austin attracts the best and brightest in Texas, which makes the city a great place to live and work.
cons: Your group matters more than anything, but across the University there's been a trend towards 'centralization' which has accompanied introduction of a fee-for-services model even within departments. I get that there are budget cuts, but my group brings in $1M+ in grants, we pay 50% overhead, and we're still expected to contract through the University for things like IT services and Machine shop time. We make more than enough money to hire admins (which we seem to need due to the complexity of our grant requirements) but we're forced to rely more and more on a small pool of Department and College staff who help everyone but as a result aren't perfectly familiar with anyone's work. A lot of the stuff that even 10 years ago was handled by dedicated personnel is now being shifted to researchers. If you make a professor clean his own lab and office you're paying $60/hr for a janitor for the time they're doing that instead of their research - you're not saving money, you're just hiding your loss in the margins.

review_title: Some opportunities exist for an HR person at UT but pay is low and workload is heavy.
pros:
Good benefits including insurance and retirement. 
Large organization allows for more opportunities to move, and potentially advance, within the university.
Good leadership with President Fenves.
UT has money to develop its technology resources, which may make your job easier or more efficient. 
Typically have the opportunity for a merit raise each year.
cons:
Pay tends to be low. 
Managers tend to be compensated disproportionately higher and receive greater increases when compared to front line workers.
Workloads, at least in Human Resources titles, tends to be very heavy.
There tends to be disparities in workload within units - some positions may be heavily overloaded while others are underutilized.
Structured opportunities for managers to recognize and appreciate employees are slim and underutilized.  
You have to pay for parking and there is an 18 month wait for garage spaces.  You can buy cheaper “A” parking but spaces nearest campus fill up early, relegating those who do not come in a seven am to lots in the outer reaches on campus.

The 2 weeks paid time off around the holidays is amazing, doesn't come out of your vacation allowance.  Every department/office is different so I can only speak to mine, and it's awesome!!
cons: The pay isn't very competitive at times.  Raises don't happen every year or even every other year.  If you do get one, it's only about 2% which doesn't even cover the cost of inflation or rising insurance premiums so in reality I make less and less every year.  Raises should be based on how well the employee is doing, to compensate their hard work, not on if they got one last year or not.  If you got one last year, you won't get one this year.  The only way to get paid more is to move from job to job.  This is disheartening because I LOVE my current position and don't want to leave it.  But if I continue getting this pay, I will have to move on.  Parking is horrible for staff.  Every year they take away more and more staff parking (A permits).  This is very challenging and frustrating.  The parking garage wait is about 2-4 years too.

review_title: State Agency - So about what you expect
pros: Good retirement benefits.  Great healthcare benefits. Security in your job once you make it past the probationary period. Overall the workplace culture and my colleagues are happy and pleasant.
cons:
If you need anything other than basic healthcare benefits then it starts to get pricy.  And parking is a nightmare.  Be prepared to pay for it and walk a lot.  There is nothing that is convenient or free at UT Austin.  
And because all of your colleagues are state employees that have probably worked here for many  years in the exact same job, don't expect them to volunteer a lot of information or explanation.  There is almost zero training on the archaic and very specific UT Austin systems.  They will point you to wiki's and broken links and then just shrug when you have question.  You are very much on your own to learn your job.  They just say  "That's how UT is."
Staff is at the bottom of the totem pole at UT.  First students (customers).  Then faculty.  Then the staff.  And when it comes to salaries - expect a very modest annual increase.  No one will get rich  on staff (unless your in athletics or the President's office).  But the payoff will be the security at retirement.

review_title: Salary repression, wage stagnation, and low morale
pros:
The Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin has truly unique and rich cultural resources, and the staff that work with the materials and researchers are an intelligent and dedicated group of people.
The University offers a good health benefits package for single people, and a portion of your salary is automatically put towards a retirement plan. University employees can ride Austin public transportation for free, and for employees that drive to work, they offer pre-tax deduction of parking payment.
cons:
The Harry Ransom Center suffers from wage stagnation and salary repression. There is a large disconnect between the administration and non-curatorial staff, and so the morale of most staff is at rock-bottom. There are no metrics to measure productivity/achievement so raises are made arbitrarily by the director. Merit raises are used to bolster the salaries of newer staff members and not to reward significant achievements.
The University does not offer employees certain benefits which could make up for poor salaries. For example, staff must pay for parking and pay to use the gym facilities. Concealed carry of weapons is now allowed on campus.

pros:
Being in a research lab my position was grant-funded which may only apply to a small number of people reading this review. From this standpoint, the University has many well funded investigators that bring in large amounts of grant funding and thus provide a large number of graduate and post-graduate positions. 

Much of my experience at UT was specific to the investigator that I worked for, but there are a number of things about the university that make it a great place to work.
- Its located in Austin. Austin is a great place to live and offers great places to live and play.
- The university provides a number if career enrichment opportunities and is actively engaged in helping its employees develop new skills.
- The pay scale seems to be appropriate for the cost of living in Austin. Having worked at a few other universities I can say this isn't always the case.
- Health benefits and retirement plan
cons:
There are a few things that could be improved, but, in my opinion, they aren't deal breakers.
- Parking is a bit of a problem. UT employs many people and there just isn't enough parking to accommodate all of the students and the employees. The cost is actually cheaper than other large universities but its still annoying.
- At least in research positions, there isn't a lot of upward mobility or large increases in salary. Most research personnel are only at at the UT as a stepping stone to another better paying position so its not much of a big deal.

cons: Vague expectations in some roles, not yet clearly defined. Specific needs for their culture with general comments and no concrete examples on improvement. Strict time policy and limited flexibility on external experience vs. long term staff who have been there for a while. They value loyalty and seem to be overly cautious of new ideas. Somewhat of a micro-manager feel unfortunately, but with good intentions. I do believe they value their employees and mean well, but the culture seems to have an unwritten / not-well defined criteria that prohibits some creativity and flexibility for new ideas. Scripted responses and lack of trust with making employees feel empowered seems to be a personal struggle I had. They are very hands on and it's almost "guilty" until proven innocent mindset. Understandable to a degree with having to prove yourself and productivity, respect for different perspectives seemed to be misunderstood.

review_title: Antiquated, restrictive policies in the Engineering College
pros:
Working for UT has some great benefits, including:
- excellent healthcare options
- generous sick, vacation and comp time policies
- paid time off during for the Christmas through New Years week
- a large campus with great museums, restaurants, sporting events, etc.
- lots of job growth potential if you're open to transferring between colleges/departments.
cons:
- Stifling, antiquated work/life balance policies applied to the Dean's staff at the engineering college. It's completely absurd and is causing people to leave. It's a stuffy, restrictive, micro-managing culture that is coming from the top and trickling down. 
- Stingy, unrealistic meal allotments for engineering staff that have to travel - and there are many of us.
- Ludicrous, laughable policies regarding what can and can't be purchased with the corporate credit card vs. personal credit card vs. house accounts, etc, etc.. blah, blah, blah. It seems to change every week. Why is this so complicated? 
- Zero job growth potential and employee development on my team. So, people are resigning and moving to other colleges on campus that "get it."
- Lots of legacy employees here.. the ones who have had their job for 20+ years, aren't open to change and are just counting down the days until retirement. 
- If you drive to work, you have to pay for parking.

review_title: JJ Pickle Research Campus - Institute for Geophysics: Gulf Basin Depositional Synthesis Project
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant (Temporary Employee) in Austin, TX
pros: Environment is very intimate, with a relatively small number of employees consisting of undergrad, masters, and doctoral students, assisting mostly senior level research geologists with various tasks. Excellent network of highly qualified and accredited researchers to work with, some of whom take on graduate students. GBDS has a very large database of GIS data, continental and offshore seismic lines in and around the Gulf of Mexico (mostly proprietary), academic publications, and mapping software, made available to sponsors and affiliated researchers (including graduate and doctoral students).
cons: Funding for GBDS comes directly from sponsors, most of which are industry related oil and gas companies, meaning all department finances (employee salaries, research funding, etc.) are entirely reliant on the success and momentum of oil and gas and their market value - as such, GBDS is heavily controlled by politics. Additionally, undergraduate student workers have predominantly one job, digitizing well logs, which equates to tracing a line with a mouse for hours on end; the environment is also very quiet and can be a bit dreary and depressing at times.

pros: Large, fairly nice campus. Educational opportunities through actual enrollment (one free class per semester for full-time staff) or by auditing for no credit. Many positive interactions with the students we serve.  Decent retirement plan and health insurance.
cons: Many business processes are extremely inefficient, and the current movement toward cloud-based solutions will probably not fix things.  Staff is very top-heavy with clueless and (often) unqualified management.  Increasing incidents of age discrimination; staff older than ~45-50 had better prepare to be laid off/fired,even if they have a consistently excellent work record.  University offers some good academic programs (mainly liberal arts, natural sciences, and engineering), but as a whole is overrated and management is abusing the staff that keep everything running.  Many tenure-track professors leave for better opportunities.  No COL raises for regular staff in five years and very little increase for professors during the same period.

review_title: Good place to work as a TA if you have a good mentor
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The University of Texas takes decent care of its graduate student assistants, many of whom receive tuition assistance/ waivers and excellent health insurance as part of the job. With a primary instructor who values the TA and invests in his/her/their professional development, and a large pool of smart students, UT-Austin can be a rewarding place to teach.
cons:
While the tuition assistance/ waiver and health insurance for graduate student teaching assistants is generous, the living stipend is insufficient. UT's graduate student assembly recently set up a working group to assess the adequacy of compensation, and the fact is, the stipend simply does not cut it beyond basic living expenses, especially since rent is going up very quickly all over Austin. Heaven help you if you want to save any money or have car troubles. 
Also, I was surprised that UT did not have any mandatory TA training. I am not in favor of requiring a lot of mandatory activities, but I thought it was odd that people who are spending 20 hours of each week on TA duties were not required to attend training on university course/ grading policies and course tech management.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
Their health-care program is pretty good and since I'm working for the University, I get the in-state tuition rates. 
Also, the other students are very friendly and the whole University environment is quite amazing.
The campus also has multiple great facilities students can use.
Also, you get to ride the public transportation system all around Austin for free with your student card.
cons:
The cons I'll list here are specific to my department and my supervisor - I think this is very difficult to apply to all other departments. 
In the Civil Engineering department, in my specific field, there are very few options for supervisors and some of them even have issues talking to each other. 
The total salary is also quite pitiful, especially after taking out tuition and health-care expenses. Austin isn't as expensive as New York or San Francisco, but having $1700 a month (after taxes) to pay for rent ($900), bills ($300) and food ($300) leaves little to no wiggle room, making my life a month-to-month situation. I've been here for 4 months already and still haven't been able to buy a couch because of this.
Lastly, my supervisor is extremely demanding and often expects his PhD students to work over weekends and holidays on his research, forcing them to completely abandon their own research.

review_title: Hierarchical organization with an amazing disregard for permanent staff and graduate students
pros: Most of the University's faculty and resources are top-notch. Interesting mix of people, projects and ideas. Great setting in a vibrant city. A great place to study, and if you take a staff position, make use of the staff educational benefit and then move on.
cons: Compensation for staff is subsistence level (most can't even afford to live in relative proximity to campus and have long commutes). No compensation adjustments for staff within the past 5 years and layoffs are not uncommon. Staff cannot access campus gym facilities without being required to pay an additional fee. Expensive insurance premiums. Dead end career paths are common, so many employees stay in the same positions over most their career. Little incentive to change well-entrenched practices that no longer serve the organization's mission. Policies are routinely established by management with little or no input from staff, which often leads to unanticipated repercussions. Staff and graduate students have no way to organize to demand changes (unions are illegal, and existing organizations are largely ineffective). Graduate student jobs are not compensated fairly. And staff who are also students, you should know that the staff educational benefit applies to all courses EXCEPT dissertation credits (officials at the highest level have declined requests to reconsider modifying the policy). Limited support for graduate students in the way of fellowships.

pros: Large diverse environment of great and talented people.  Very few institutions have the scale, scope, and quality of UT.  This is a great community with great pride in the public brand of the institution.  Might be worth working here for those interested in making Austin your home.  This is not a great place for young entrepreneurial staff.  The machine will tear you a part. Great place for those looking for a moderate pace that can be insulated from the realities of the private sector.
cons: With limited resources to go around there is so much angst and agitation around major decisions and making changes.  If you want to make change here, you have to put your neck on the line - not worth it too many people.  Creates a very change resistance culture.  Numerous employees have been there for a long time are hanging on to keep their jobs.  Will not support anything that puts their job at risk.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Austin, TX
pros: Great benefits and support for incoming students
cons: Long hours, hard to transition outside of given tasks.

pros: Nice campus, excellent research and mentors
cons: Lab facilities could use some updating

pros: Efficient and Light-Hearted work setting
cons: Lower pay than i would like

pros: Good pay, flexible schedule, can study
cons: No cons, it's a great place!

pros: nice place to work and live
cons: non, great time to work and live

pros: great core facility for scientists
cons: hiring process was very slow.

pros: Very good school to attend.
cons: The school has no cons

pros: Can take long lunches, flexible holiday schedule if you can get away. Get free clothes sometimes. The city of Austin and leaving work everyday to enjoy it.
cons: Pretty much everything about UT athletics is questionable. The people, most of the coaches, the micro management, the pay, the respect for employees, the overtime without pay, the last minute planning and travel, the unrewarding projects, the sour attitudes of other employees, its all awful. HR WILL literally tell you that you are expendable because apparently everyone wants to work here. Just don't. If you want to keep a bit of passion and excitement for what you love to do, work somewhere else. UT athletics will kill your desire to do what you love. Everyone complains about the same things here so i don't understand why nothing is changing. Theres no room for improvement, no advancement of skill or knowledge at your disposal. They will title you completely wrong, apply a bizarre job code so they don't have to pay you fairly for your actual job description. They are sneaky about it, but i have no idea how they get away with it.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Austin, TX
pros: Excellent employee benefits, comfortable working environment, potential for interacting and working with some of the best and brightest people you could ever hope to meet, potential for lots of wonderful and interesting challenges.
cons: Three words -- Rice Bowl Politics.  The bigger the University, the bigger and nastier the internal in-fighting can be.  If you get in with the right people, it can be the greatest place you've ever been.  But management can be changed on you overnight and it can suddenly become worst than your worst nightmare, especially if there are mandatory budget cuts across the entire University.  Faculty are most highly valued, especially if they publish a lot and most especially if they can bring in big grant money.

review_title: Administrative Assistant (Department of Theatre and Dance)
pros: Spiritually fulfilling for creatives, great professional experience, overall positive energy in the office day-to-day, healthcare benefits and education credits if you stay over a year.
cons: Worst pay scale imaginable for a career employee. Ineffective communication between departments, individuals always seeking to point fingers at each other instead of helping, grand expectations with little payoff. You get "PTO" instead of overtime pay and then they are sour when you want to utilize it. Can't unplug on sick days, you get called and texted and emailed even when you have doctor's orders to be resting. Too much scrutiny with very little appreciation. Expect your workload to continually increase.  All paperwork is constantly turned in late, making it nearly impossible to meet deadlines and you will be blamed.

review_title: It's slow, but it's getting there
job_title: Central IT Worker in Austin, TX
pros:
* Good health benefits package
* Lots of worker protection policies: very secure
* Relatively easy mobility across organizational units (lateral transfers, etc.)
* State employment, so it's fairly easy to do an acceptable job
cons:
* EVERYTHING  is required to have 'consensus' before proceeding, leading to a lot of aborted projects, slow time to implement and high amount of scope creep
* The working environment is highly politicized, requiring careful negotiation for any meaningful improvements
* Other organizational units (e.g., departments or colleges) can choose to ignore central IT if they have enough clout
* Grudges can come back to haunt you (even after several years...)
* Pay is low, compared to private industry 
* No real advancement path or career enhancement for technical folks

pros: It's nice working at a university. People are usually nice. The vacation time and sick time that you earn are you work is pretty good. It's really nice to have winter break off (and still get paid). The job is straight forward. You know what to expect everyday. Not usually surprises. I really enjoy working here. I definitely think that the pros out weigh the cons.
cons: UT has a lot of policies and procedures that you have to follow. There is always 1,000+ rules for everything you or the students to follow. Nothing is simple. I understand why it is strict, but sometimes it is just a pain. The maternity leave benefit is horrible. You have to use all of your over time, comp time, vacation time and sick time. After you run out of all of those, you get leave without pay. When you return to work, you are left with no vacation time and no sick time. Another con is parking. Parking is a beast. It is hard to move up positions without getting a master's degree.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
UT Austin is a solid research university with a good reputation
Depending on the department, there are many distinguished faculty members
Austin is the best place in Texas to live
The campus is lovely
-
cons: Like most universities, UT Austin is following the corporate model, which involves downsizing teaching faculty and the kinds of administrative positions that help departments run, while massively expanding funding for the kinds of administrative positions that decide who to fire and how best to make other people take on their workload, among an already overworked and underpaid body of faculty and staff. Meanwhile, while Austin is wonderful, it is still in Texas, and it is illegal for public employees in Texas to unionize, and soon students will be allowed to carry  concealed weapons in classrooms and dorms.

review_title: Seven years spent within university administration have been rewarding, thus far.
pros: Currently I enjoy working with my colleagues most of all. They challenge me on a daily bases with work issues and as a result there is never a dull moment. We tackle complex problems on behalf of all university departments and I enjoy problem solving and working through issues until they are solved.
cons: The budget crises has gone on for a long time. The university is definitely not the place to work if you want to get rich. But if you want to grow your career knowledge and become an expert in your field, then you can definitely hone your craft and gain experience as a trade off.

review_title: Laid back place to work with mostly great people
pros: I enjoy working at UT, and have wonderful things to say about the developer community around campus.  The environment is pretty laid back, and the benefits are pretty nice.  Until recently, there was a training program for developers which provided a great way to break into the programming industry.  It is currently dormant, but is expected to start again soon.
cons: The recent effects of the recession have pretty much ensured that our already lackluster salaries won't be improving any time soon.  Pay is not at all competitive with the private sector, and probably never will be.  In addition to the local politics of the university, working there also means dealing with the results of state and national politics, which can often be a pain.

pros: winter break; leave policy (carryover vacation and sick time from year to year); campus atmosphere; health insurance is okay (same or better in most corporations); free access to public transportation; the staff educational benefit is potentially useful, but it has some silly limitations, so do some research to make sure it will apply to the program you are interested in
cons: The classified staff person's experience at UT is drastically different from the A&P, executive, academic or athletic division experience and hugely disappointing. Pay is extremely low and raises are rare (and typically a fraction of what they should be). Parking is expensive (use public transportation if possible); the vision insurance isn't as good as in most corporations; the distributed administrative and management system is inefficient and hampers innovation and promotion pathways. The current effort to fix this isn't very promising as it appears it is being managed haphazardly and primarily as a power grabbing opportunity. It's a good place to lay low for awhile; otherwise, give it a miss.

review_title: A Great Place for Students to Work and Gain Valuable Sales Experience
pros:
Texas Student Media is a great place to work for students interested in sales and advertising. It offers a very flexible schedule for student life where all of the standard academic vacations and class times are easy to fit in. 

The management is very friendly and helpful, and the TSM atmosphere is very "family"-esque, making it a great organization to meet people and a great place to work.
cons: There were really no major downsides other than the fact that printed media has substantially fallen to the wayside in lieu of digital media. Thus as an account executive responsible for print advertising, it becomes very hard to attract new business in an oversaturated and tech-savvy market.

job_title: ITS Student Consultant in Austin, TX
pros:
-They are pretty accommodating about scheduling your shifts around your classes and exams
-The office is located right on campus at the FAC
-Work with fellow students
-Friendly environment
cons:
-You will receive calls you have no idea how to handle and the internal documentation is pretty messy to sift through. This happens at least a couple times a week and can be stressful as you want to handle the call in a timely fashion while also providing a correct solution.
-On the opposite spectrum of it being stressful, the job can be really dull at times. There are periods where you'll receive non-stop call after call, and periods where you'll receive very few.
-People are generally friendly, but it can be tough to find help with difficult problems. You will usually just be told to check the internal documentation or sent down a rabbit hole (eg. x says talk to y, y says talk to z, z says they don't know).
-Inevitably, some people end up carrying more of the workload than others

pros: Great benefits: medical, tuition assistance, on-site medical clinic and pharmacy. For those interested, UT also offers many resources to help you become a better educator. Your experience as a TA/AI will vary, of course, depending on the department / division you're in.
cons: Parking is a challenge. But if you're attending classes, anyway, you've probably already figured out a solution that you can live with. Of course, TA duties my require you to be on campus on days you don't have class and might have otherwise been able to stay at home.

job_title: Public Affairs Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: A shared community of people who genuinely care about you. Goal-driven people who continue to learn and encourage you to do the same.
cons: At times staff and employees could be more attentive to what’s going on with their own people. Management failed to pay attention and listen on numerous occasions and  communication could have been more transparent. The last thing new management should do is impose change and a new culture and way of doing things. Need more team cohesion and community building. I felt like employees didn’t really want to learn about each other. There was a lot of talk about support and open communication, but these values were not practiced by all. With the change of management, the team culture went from being collaborative and open to closed. It was sad to see the culture shift like this overnight.

review_title: Higher education administration has its ups and downs.
pros: Working at UT means working for one of the largest employers in Austin and also aligning yourself with a community of students and alumni who are passionate about their alma mater.
cons: When you work at UT, you also work for the state. This has some advantages as it relates to job stability but it also means a lot of odd politics, crazy red tape, and a greater likelihood of apathetic/slow employees. In addition, changes in leadership dramatically impact school/department priorities. Also, there is minimal strategic vision for most departments. Lastly, because tenured faculty are the top dogs, everyone else has the potential to feel like red headed step children.

review_title: Somewhat bureaucratic but high quality scientific research ecosystem
pros:
Many facilities available for research
Being a very large organization, most of the times you can find the research equipment/software access to share 
Highly successful pool of people around
Possibility of getting undergraduate assistance
Equipment pricing are somewhat cheaper as the UT Austin has some Tax exemption and agreements with some vendors
TACC (Supercomputing system)
Nice shuttle service (if you stay in some of those areas well served by UT shuttles);  bus frequency in far west area  ~10 min during day time!
Library service is great as almost all scientific journals from various fields are accessible as university hosts many specializations
cons:
Parking is not great if you are commuting by car; people need to park away from office and walk around 15 minutes to reach office even if they arrive earlier (~ 8:00 am)
Somewhat process and regulation orientation bureaucratic organization. It is obvious due to its huge size

job_title: Center for Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering in Austin, TX
pros: Flexible hours; my obligation was to finish projects, not to cover a shift during a certain time. Leniancy if I had a big test or assignment due and needed to request teh day off, last minute, as long as I made up the time asap. Experience with world-class projects, secure research funding, proximity to classes. I even got my name mentioned in several published research papers. And it's a part-time job that still looks good on a resume.
cons: No room to move up unless you enter graduate school. Usually not able to continue working if any lapse in enrollement (i.e. to work over the summer, you have to be a student over the summer, or get special exception). Hard to be recognizied much beyond an acknowledgement in a research paper.

pros: Working at the University of Texas was a great experience and has given me skills to help with any leadership positions I may take in the future. The professor I worked for provided consistent feedback and always let me know what I need to improve on.
cons: The grading took up a lot of time and sometimes it was difficult to keep up. Angry students sometimes try to take out their bad work on the TAs and complain when they don't get the A they were wanting. Be prepared to deal with a lot of complaining students if you hold them to a high standard of work like my supervising professor did.

review_title: Graduate studies, or why academia is still relevant
pros: Being a doctoral candidate working with top-notch scientists has been a great experience so far and hopefully my degree and professional experience here will help me advance to a very fulfilling and promising career.
cons: Graduate Students are generally grossly underpaid and considered cheap labor. This is an academia - wide phenomenon, not necessarily specific to UT Austin. Since Austin is a booming city, it has become increasingly more difficult for graduate students to maintain affordable lifestyles. It is no wonder that more and more of the brightest college graduates opt for exiting academia to the job market soon after graduation. I believe that this will in turn hurt universities tremendously.

pros:
UT Austin is a second tier research university with several esteemed faculty, however, there is great exposure to high end research via seminars and events put on by the departments.
The location of the university is excellent.  Right in the heart of Austin, near downtown, and easily accessible by bike, bus, car.
UT graduate housing is an excellent way to live alone for cheap.  Elsewhere is almost too much for what the pay is.
cons: The pay is too low for Austin cost of living if alone.  With roommates it is doable.  There is little exposure to other fields other than academia (at least in the chemistry department).  Not enough focus on other types of job opportunities.  Parking is atrocious.  Construction around the center of campus is invasive and difficult to navigate.

review_title: Great Place To Start, But You'll Have To Create Your Own Opportunities If You Want To Stay
pros: Flexible, no hassle to take a day off if needed.  Excellent healthcare that is free to the employee.  Excellent opportunities to learn, BEST LIBRARY, museums and access to knowledge of any kind.  Staff benefits are decent with discounts, free bus/train fare with ID.  There are opportunities to better oneself/position if they utilize the staff education benefit and other top of the line resources that are offered.
cons: Pay is not a living wage, extra job(s) are needed, and raises are really hard to come by.  Admin are not treated very well by other staff.  The amount of work for one person is really the job of 2 or 3.

review_title: Wonderful place to work if you can afford to
pros: UT is a super place to work in an administrative capacity. In most colleges, effort is appreciated, encouraged and rewarded. The benefits are really great in terms of health insurance, flexibility and pension, if you just hang in there. There are many opportunities for those interested in changing directions.
cons: The pay is abysmal compared to the private sector. If you're married and have a working partner, it's a nice supplementary income. However, salaries haven't kept up with the cost of living by a long shot. Many fellow employees have to commute from out of town because they can't afford to live in the city of Austin. Also, you have to pay to park, which only cuts into your salary further.

pros:
Preface: I worked as a resident assistant with the Division of Housing and Food Services.

My supervisor was incredibly helpful in developing myself as a person and helping me excel in my career and the balance with school as a student was very well managed, ensuring that I was able to handle both. My personal team of coworkers was also very positive and helpful in a number of issues.
cons: There are some organizational issues involving the higher-ups and new people in these higher positions but this should ease up over the next couple of years. Other organizational issues in scheduling where some areas may be overstaffed while others are understaffed. However, they continually look for ways to improve their process and help their employees and are ironing out issues continuously.

pros: UT Austin has incredible resources. The students, on the whole, are great. My employee benefits were good and I felt that I grew as a person by working for UT.
cons: My department was less than collegial. It was enormous, impersonal, and there was strife among faculty that kept various initiatives from being timely or productive. Certain labor practices were in place that have since been repealed on account of questionable legality. Lastly -- and this does not strictly apply to UT -- open carry is a major reason that I have not pursued further employment in higher education in Texas.

review_title: Please do your research before working here!
pros: Get to serve the UT athletes and interact with them and be their home away from home when they dine here.
cons: Poor pay, Worse Management, Poor working conditions,  High turnover rate, Often understaffed. Paid temps and new hires more than existing employees, Rarely allowed to bake muffins for the athletes even though they asked for them and loved them and all ingredients were already approved by lead dietician. Employees are asked to go above and beyond often by Management, if employees ask for anything like a day off without two weeks notice, that is considered an employee privilege.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
Grateful to have a job 
Beautiful campus  
Flexible hours if needed and great benefits 
Brilliant people to work with in the natural sciences
cons:
Highest departments are almost impossible to work with; staff are leaving 
Communication to staff almost non-existent in upper departments
Clerical staff are not valued; managers make what we do seem unimportant
Cannot make a living on just this salary; supplement with a part-time job
Hiring freeze

pros: This place has a lot of flexibility with work hours.  As bosses who understand that everyone has their emergencies need to leave, you may do it.
cons:
One of the downfall of working here is that you're located in the basement, and you may lose track of time.

The program language used here is strictly LabVIEW so there aren't much opportunities to code in a different language.

Also file management is a clutter mess, you will find that your files are missing and sometimes it's hard to know who has the latest version to a program.

Managements may throw some tasks that are beyond the ability of what you signed up for.

review_title: ARL great place to work if you really like engineering and don't like corporate BS...
job_title: Engineering Research Associate in Austin, TX
pros:
Laid back atmosphere, in that there's not a lot of pressure to work overtime or meet stringent goals.  They expect engineers to generally manage their own time and tasks, talking to senior engineers when necessary to proceed with personal work.

Challenging work...lots of DSP, pushing embedded processors and systems to the limit, advanced analog design both in power and signal filtering.

Very little BS..as in the kind you get at a corporation, such as endless meetings, pointless emails, idiot bosses (all management comes from the inside and are engineers).
cons: The saying goes "you'll never get rich working here".  Probably limited potential to become a manager as well, since engineers stay here so long.

pros: The IT department at University of Texas provides a good work life balance to employees. People are friendly.  I get enough time to finish my project and don't feel rushed.  You get an option of Windows or Mac as your desktop or laptop computer. IT departments across campus use a mix of old and new technologies.  Large mIssion critical applications are written in Natural/Adabas languages on the mainframe.  There are quite a few applications that use newer technologies such as Linux, Python, Java, PHP, .Net/C#, MySql, Oracle and others.  There has been a push recently to move towards newer technologies.
cons: Large mission critical applications are written in outdated languages such as Natural/Adabas on the mainframe.  Salaries are lower than industrial average. Salary freezes in IT department for several years.

review_title: Lots of work; lots of learning.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
-The other graduate students in my field (mechanical engineering) are among the brightest around.
-Somewhat flexible hours...it is a research appointment, after all.
-Getting paid to get a degree is a pretty sweet deal, even if you're not actually putting much in the bank.
cons:
-Pay is minimal...this is hard to complain about, though, given that I will come out with a Masters.  However, even a 2-3 thousand dollar bump would mean a lot at this pay level.
-You work a lot--seriously.  Three courses with homework plus seemingly endless hours in the laboratory means that you don't have as much personal time as you would in a typical 9 to 5 appointment.  That is entirely dependent on which laboratory you choose to work in, obviously, so your mileage may vary.

review_title: It's great to be surrounded by brilliant, creative people, but the pay is not the best.
pros: Your co-workers are likely to be diverse, smart, and funny, and your managers are open to suggestions. There are several extra paid holidays around the end of the year, and many offices are flexible about work hours.
cons: The pay is not great and unlikely to improve soon, what with the state tightening its budget belt. Four years and no raises, yet health insurance premiums for family members continue to rise, making for a net loss in pay. It's not always permitted to work from home, even doing the type of work that could easily translate there.

review_title: A diverse ecosystem that offers many opportunities but often withf a reduced pay scale.
pros: Excellent colleagues spread across a broad array of knowledge domains. Access to cutting edge world-class infrastructure, technology, research facilities and projects. The ability to impact the world by contributing to projects that directly improve global conditions or promote education and awareness. Long and frequent holidays with a progressive vacation leave and good benefits package. Generally very flexible with balancing family and work.
cons: Reduced pay rate. Limited options in choice of benefit package options. Limited vertical career advancement. An almost endless ban on salary increases, bonuses and promotion opportunities.

review_title: Stellar academic unit committed to being the best, enhanced by a friendly community
pros:
Outstanding academics
World-class research
Science makes a major impact on society
High value placed on student service
Collegial atmosphere
Friendly students and faculty
Opportunities for travel
Opportunities for professional development
Interesting subjects pursued by students, faculty, and scientists
One of the crown jewels of the University of Texas and the national geoscience community
cons:
High expectations (not a con for good employees)
Flexibility required, willingness to wear many hats
The sense of community between the major research units could improve.

review_title: Politics run rampant.  President does not live values.
pros: The frontline staff are amazing and loyal.  They believe in the mission of the University of Texas.  Bright people who want to do the right thing, but are derailed by politics.
cons: The President is more interested in keeping his job than doing his job.  He makes decisions that play to donors or politics rather than what is in the best interests of the students, faculty, or staff.  His short term appointment from the Board of Regents means that he does not want to implement any new programs to take Texas forward.  This prevents new, innovative programs from being implemented.  The absence of improvement led to me looking for another job.

review_title: The Science is Booming but the politics are overwhelming
pros: I definitely enjoyed my research, collaborations, and flexible schedule at UT.  The facilities are great, (some of) the faculty are generally interested in the new Dean has made significant positive changes to the Molecular Biosciences department.
cons: Too many politics that affect the daily research of many labs.  Too many of the younger professors feel 'bullied' by the senior faculty.  And many of the tenure professors do not actually care about the research in their labs or the members within.

pros: Fairly casual atmosphere, good benefits, great staff colleagues.
cons: Hurry up and wait expectations from the Tower down. Pay rates have not kept up with the increased cost of living in Austin over the past decade. Staff are often overlooked when campus-wide matters are discussed, e.g. safety, equity, etc. It takes a strong personality to stay at UT for more than a few years. Most of my colleagues are doing the jobs of at least two people in their UT position and a large number have second jobs outside of UT.

review_title: "Full Time" is half your research and half TA work
pros: This report of salary is specific to the Plant Biology/Integrative Biology Department(s).  Depending on which class you are assigned to assist, it can be very easy work, and cost much less than the 20 hours expected of you.  The rest of your "full time" is spent on your own research leading to your graduate degree as well as coursework.  Benefits are EXCELLENT for what we do (and free).   University amenities and services are excellent.
cons: Depending on which class you are assigned it can be a real pain in the %$! and possibly cost you MORE than the 20 hours you are assigned--you have to cut off the professor sometimes.

pros: The university offers good benefits.  The workforce is diverse and the community surrounding students and faculty/staff is vibrant.  They do a good job of creating an environment conducive to learning.
cons: For my department, there is very little work-life balance.  Management has chosen to reduce staff in favor of less people doing more work without any adjustment in pay.  In a city that continues to get more expensive every day, it might unfortunately lead to defections of hard-working, good staff members as they can no longer afford to work and live in the community.   In the department, there is limited opportunities for advancement and cross training.  Budgetary cuts have also eliminated the  opportunities to attend community/university conferences that are vital to collaborating with counterparts at different academic institutions.

job_title: Teaching Assistant/Graduate Student in Austin, TX
pros: Austin is a wonderful town, the department I work in is relatively drama-free. I have only had to go without funding for one summer in my 3 years here.
cons: My adviser is not very good at advising graduate students, and I feel that the department administration doesn't know or doesn't care. I also got conned into an unfortunate situation regarding my status as a masters vs phd student. I don't know if this came from my adviser or the department. Either way, I'm feeling pretty screwed. Also, I failed to receive a teaching position this most recent summer session.

review_title: I am a graduate student in the department of environmental & water resources engineering
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Strong community among graduate students in the department, very friendly relationships with professors & advisors, a lot of resources here (if you look for them) to help you achieve your goals. Collaboration is encouraged. Easy to have a great work-life balance. Flexible schedule. Austin is awesome. If you are funded, it's a great life.
cons: Not all advisors are created equal: my advisor has too many students to deal with and so I hardly see him/her. Not a problem if you are extremely self-motivated and patient and know exactly what to do... I personally would have appreciated more guidance. But this is highly dependent on your advisor. Some of my peers are definitely overworked.

review_title: Freshman Research Initiative Mentor & Chemistry Stockroom Worker
job_title: Freshman Research Initiative Mentor & Chemistry Stockroom Worker in Austin, TX
pros: Great hours, convenient location for students, all around a perfect college job for CNS students! (both jobs) In down time, you can work on homework, and the pay is very good for not having all that much work
cons: Depending on which stockroom you are in or whose lab you are working in, it is possible that the area may feel a bit disorganized which makes your job harder, since you may need to restock something but be unable to find it.

pros: Decent pay as a T.A., great professor to work with. You also get with many positions free student health insurance (Bluecross Blueshield) and tuition reduction.
cons: In the coming academic year of 2016-2017, concealed carry will be allowed on campus. This is extremely troubling because just this year, there was a case of a student threatening a professor and T.A.. How do you think that would have turned out if there was a gun involved? In addition, treatment and salary of T.A.s vary greatly by department. I was in a department which didn't have any issues, but I've heard horror stories from other departments.

review_title: Fun if you already bleed orange but overall staff are undervalued
pros: Good benefits (especially the staff education benefit, health insurance and retirement options), work environments can be great depending on your supervisor. There are a lot of trainings and there can be room for growth, but it may require switching departments or colleges.
cons: Salary is not commensurate with experience or comparable positions elsewhere; there's no adjusting for cost of living increases. Ironically, education is undervalued by hiring managers

review_title: A Fun Place for Students to Work
pros: Worked here as an undergraduate college students to help pay the bills. It was the best job I had in undergraduate. The pay was minimum wage, but the experience and the kids make up for the low pay. They are flexible with your school schedule and during the holiday breaks, there are plenty of opportunities for you to come in and make some extra cash. The centers are filled with diverse employees and its a job where its not only acceptable but preferred that you come in wearing casual clothes you can move in. If you have any interest in working with kids, this is a great experience.
cons: The minimum wage pay may be the only con that I can think of.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: UT Austin has a lot of opportunities to get involved in research that you are interested in. It takes some time to really look around for something you want to be involved in, but once you show interest and talk to the professors, there are a lot of opportunities and autonomy afforded to you. I work in a molecular biology lab, and within 3 months I was being recognized for the progress I was making. After a semester, I was getting compensated for my time at a pretty good rate of $12/hr.
cons: As a student, balancing research with my class schedule is a little challenging, and many professors won't take you on in their labs unless you show that you can commit around 15 hrs + per week.

job_title: Academic Advising Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: Great Benefits (free medical for employees, for dependents and/or spouses to be covered there is a charge), wonderful colleagues, intellectual stimulation, nice work space, side benefits like seeing cool speakers (usually free), museums (also free), and sporting events (not free)
cons: Low pay for staff and lack of defined career tracks, definitely third class behind faculty and students.  Must pay 400+ a year to park at my job.  Lack of flexibility for example working remotely not allowed for many positions.

review_title: Energetic Worker - Less than satisfied with workload
pros: Stable work environment.  Very good if you want a flexible schedule and want little to no responsibilities.  You will have job forever, if you want.  It is rare that someone will come to your door demanding something to be done in the same day. If you are lazy, this is the position for you.
cons: Very slow at many times.  Not very challenging.  Not that much room to get a better position without qualifications.  There are many people here that have been working for the university for more than 10 years, they have a guaranteed position for life, for that reason everyone I work with is very unmotivated.

review_title: Good benefits and work/life balance for IT staff. Diversity and academic personalities.
job_title: Senior Software Developer/Analyst in Austin, TX
pros: You can take part in many types of fitness, academic, etc programs and classes working at UT. Employee benefits are good. You start out getting 8 hours of vacation and 8 sick per month and vacation time grows when you are there longer. I work in IT and since it's a large organization there is a lot of room to grow and move around. I've been on a couple of different teams over the past six years.
cons: Parking is a nightmare! Sometimes you can get the state worker mentality on your team (apathetic, clock in clock out, no interest in innovation) and it is hard to get rid of them because of the nature of the workplace.

pros:
University holidays/time off-ID Capital Metro access citywide, benefits. 
I truly believed in and became a strong advocate for the program I worked for.  I loved working with those students who participated.
cons: No path of growth, no equal pay for women in the same area. (Male pay increases much different.)  No accountability.  Absolutely NO transparency between the Director and the department.

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
As a student, a flexible work schedule is key, and the Film Department's Equipment Checkout is very understanding and willing to work with you as long as provided reasonable notice of any changes. 
Working with the equipment on a daily/weekly basis provides opportunity for equipment education. Equipment checkout employees and management are helpful and happy to answer any questions you may have about camera, grip/electric, sound equipment.
Networking outside of class is important, and providing equipment for other film students (including grad students) allows just that.
cons: The only downside would be having to strictly enforce the policies of the online ordering process. Last minute ordering means that equipment will not be ready when the student needs it, and a disappointed colleague is never fun.

job_title: Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent pay for the job and competitive work environment. Great co-workers that are friendly and helpful. I work as a RA and UT gives excellent opportunities to advanced both within my department and within the overall field that I work for. Although hours can get long the work is worth it, and there are always others around to help when things get too over whelming. Management is generally good about being flexible and about taking care of their employees which is a big upshot about the job that other jobs cant really boast about.
cons: Long hours with occasional hectic work schedules.

review_title: Great work-life balance, Little growth opportunity
pros: UT Austin is an excellent place to maintain a work-life balance. Almost 2 weeks off for the winter break and regular 8-5 work schedules make this a very predictable and balanced place to work. Additionally, I feel my managers truly invest in me by encouraging me to attend at least one professional development activity per year--a conference, training, or similar activity.
cons: Tenure is valued over performance, so it is very difficult to move up at a rate you might be able to in the private sector. This can also lead to apathy among team members.

pros:
Healthcare is decent.
The only other pro I can think of is that the below cons speak mainly to my personal experience in a department at UT-COFA, and will likely (though not assuredly) fail to translate to other colleges.
cons:
I worked at the UT COFA (College of Fine Arts), and experienced such unprofessional and disrespectful treatment. My immediate supervisor openly and caustically disparaged staff members, including myself, on a consistent basis. Leadership was aware of this individual's unprofessional behavior, but to my knowledge, they took zero action to remedy it. Compensation was equally abysmal. 

I now work at a university whose culture is so opposite that of UT-COFA's, that I'm beyond grateful to have this experience in my rear view mirror.

review_title: Fantastic, world class faculty in my dept. (Music and Human Learning), but everyone is so busy, don't your hand held
pros:
world class faculty
great city
great graduate students
easy access via public transportation
good facilities
depending on your professor, good professional connections
cons: Many grad students like myself are trying to raise families and doing doctoral degrees for professional advancement, yet we are put in positions of having to do significant amounts of work while also maintaining outside professional and personal commitments.  It can be extremely stressful.

pros: The work was interesting and very fast paced. My supervisor was really flexible and let me make decisions on how I handled situations or problems I found. I know I was blessed to have great relationships with ever person I worked with. It was great place to work and being on campus was great.
cons: The pay was really low and work life balance was non-existent.  I worked way too much overtime and not much options to take time off from work or use vacation. When I left the University I had a great deal of vacation time they had to pay me out for.

pros: Great culture. Flexible working hours and conditions with lots of time off. Very good health insurance.
cons: Compensation for software developers is still extremely low compared to the private sector. You may need to change departments several times to advance beyond entry- and low-level positions and/or to find the kind of work you want to do.

review_title: PhD program in Sociology at UT Austin
pros: Large, well-resourced department with (some) professors that seem to genuinely care about graduate students. Many opportunities to learn, grow, join interesting research projects.
cons: Graduate-level classes could be improved, particularly quantitative methods for graduate students. Like most Research-1 universities, teaching is often not a priority for professors. UT also has the 2nd largest endowment after Harvard, but graduate student wages (as well as fellowships/ fellowships and tuition reductions for undergraduates) have not kept pace. Graduate students have to fight for health insurance over the summer, and have to jump through a lot of hoops to get their tuition waived so that they can do fieldwork. Tuition should be waived anytime a graduate student isn't on campus.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Consistent & decent pay, flexible hours.
cons: Be prepared to be pre-judged by your graduate student mentor your first month or so that you're not really capable of anything intelligent or much value. I felt like I wasn't really wanted by my mentor. For over half the time there, I was assigned mediocre tasks in the lab like washing & disinfecting beakers, sifting through sand and sorting grains, and just given piles of packets to read about past research projects that vaguely had anything to do with our project. Plus I only had one meeting with my actual professor I was "studying under" the whole academic year I worked there.

pros: The hours are flexible and the pay is good. You get to work on a small team of students your age and with the professor teaching the course. You also get to help kids understand new ideas which is a rewarding experience.
cons: The job can be greatly impacted by the personality and style of the professor you TA for. They can make or break whether this is an enjoyable job. The students you teach can also be a handful if you let them have too much access to your life.

job_title: Senior Marketing Associate / Marketing Manager in Austin, TX
pros: The University of Texas Office of Admissions has a great office culture that really promotes self-starting and creativity to improve the visitor experience at every step of the process. I highly recommend this student position to anyone looking to develop public speaking skills, interpersonal communication, and a direct contribution to the access to education for many underrepresented students.
cons: The hiring process is rigorous, consisting of a lengthy paper application and multiple interviews, but this is only set in place to draw the best of the best to the office. Being tasked with maintaining and updating a bevy of information about the university can also prove taxing, but these are minor cons in comparison to the benefits.

pros:
casual professional atmosphere (attire)
visible leaders who make their presence known
cons:
no opportunities for growth/advancement
low pay
very hierarchical/tall organization; minimal employee empowerment
values including workplace safety, empowerment, diversity not employed
staff feels replaceable
lots of process with little meaning

pros: This employer was certainly focused on work-life balance. There were several days off during the winter holiday season into the new year. It was a relaxed, low-stress environment. The President, Bill Powers is an inspiring leader.
cons: The health benefits were mandated by the State of Texas, so there was no way to add a domestic/same-sex partner to to the insurance.

pros: As a student, a job on campus was incredibly convenient. Everybody was patient with me if I messed something up. My bosses were easygoing, treated me with respect, and remained flexible when I or my co-workers needed a sudden schedule change. I got to listen to music while I worked and had lots of time for homework.
cons: Slacking was somewhat common but rarely reprimanded, sot others had to work harder. I worked odd hours and usually found it hard to get to work in the morning (but had fun once I got there).

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Austin, TX
pros: The standard benefits packages are great. There is a pension through TRS. Health insurance starts immediately with no preexisting condition limitations. The campus is nice and has great gyms available for a fee.
cons:
After 2009, we stopped getting raises due to budget cuts. Cost cutting included layoffs and consolidation of support staff between departments. Working in academia is no longer been a trade off of lower salary for high stability and good benefits.

Opportunities for advancement are extremely limited for staff without postgraduate degrees.

review_title: Ability to expand skills with every day work.
pros: Working in Information technology they allowed you the time to properly research most projects to expand skills. Benefits are good, with flexible schedules and casual dress code in most areas.
cons: Due to recent budget cuts raises are rare and never enough to keep up with cost of living. In most cases the only way to get a significant raise was to obtain a new job in a different area of the university. People stagnant over time due to the casual environment, I've worked with many people on campus that should have been let go long ago for more productive people.

review_title: I LOVED working at UT doing research, but could not afford it for long
pros: Every morning I woke up excited that I could do more research at the University of Texas AND get paid for it. Great work environment, and room to expand, explore, and grow in knowledge.
cons: As a university, they have to stretch their funding quite far, so they are not able to pay very much for something you could make a lot more at outside the system.

review_title: Good benefits and perks, generally easygoing workplace.
pros: Good benefits, access to lots of UT extras (gym, libraries, free access to city and university bus system). My particular office was pretty laidback and I could dress on the casual side of business casual.
cons: As a very large employer, there was sometimes a lot of bureaucracy around HR issues. Parking is expensive and/or hard to find. My office was in an off-campus location, and it sometimes felt like we weren't really a part of the campus community.

pros: Each college or school is somewhat independent, so they are frequently open to having employees offer new ideas & programs,  depending on each dean, which can also be a negative if you have someone who is bent on doing things their way.  This is a wonderful university with extensive history and an eye on the future and a solid commitment to the students & the potential of what innovations they can bring to the globe.
cons: huge organizations sometimes get caught up in processes; they are desperately wanting to embrace the latest & greatest, but it's hard to get things moving.  Each Dean can act like a ruler with NO real recourse.

review_title: Graduate research assistant at UT Austin
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: High caliber academics and gets better every year, Great social life, Austin is a great unique city, large student body, great athletics, comfortable campus atmosphere, great night life, cool people, very diverse
cons: 50,000 undergrads is too much for some people, not the best liberal arts programs, very diverse maybe wasps dont like that, it is a party school: not for everyone, Not all the professors are good for undergrad

pros: I absolutely love the work environment and interacting with the students. The work schedule is really flexible and accommodating to my course load while attending the institution. There is room for personal and professional growth.
cons: In my program, it takes up a lot of my evenings. I would like to see a the future possibility of advanced pay for the employees who stay in positions for a certain amount of time prior to promotions.

pros: Working among the faculty and students at one of the best research institutions in the nation has been a fantastic experience. I have not only  learned a great deal within my own field, but also gained valuable experience through the university in general. Living in Austin is also a tremendous plus.
cons: Of course, the "TA as indentured servant" system used across the nation does not have the long term impact it once did. Fortunately I'll gainfully employed after graduation, but I can not say the same for all of my colleagues. This is not the fault of UT in particular but of the system in general.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
-Comprehensive benefits for student workers
-Access to libraries, sports facilities and other amenities
-As an out of state Graduate Teaching Assistant, I received crucial tuition benefits and in-state status that enabled me not to take out gargantuan loans
cons:
-workload can vary tremendously depending on your professor
-class size may be 50 students one semester, to 100+ the next (as a liberal arts TA)
-miscommunication between yourself and professor can be painful, especially when it comes to grading standards or classroom etiquette

review_title: UT Is Entirely Reliant On Graduate Labor But Doesn't Pay Like It
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Some faculty are sympathetic about the untenable situation for TAs but it typically does not stop them from participating in the exploitation of our labor
cons: There is no pedagogical training for TAs despite our being the main point of contact for students in large lecture courses. It's a lot of work for very little pay especially given the cost of living in Austin. Almost all grading and logistical course support is done by TAs, so the university could not function for a single week without us, yet does not pay a living wage, which is unacceptable.

review_title: As a general assistant, my experience here spent learning about various and essential computer and communication skills.
pros: The best reasons to work here include getting to meet all the staff at the school and learning the ins and outs of doing basic needs for an corporate relationship. From making travel packets to just updating excel sheets this is a great start job.
cons: The cons include the communication. It was difficult to discuss all the issues because of the lack of communication among upper management.

review_title: Graduate School in the Humanities at UT-Austin
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Working at UT-Austin gives employees access to a wide range of resources and networking opportunities. Administration generally treats employees with respect and gratitude, and students there are enthusiastic and hard-working, for the most part.
cons: The pace at which academia moves is slow, so getting responses to questions takes longer than in industry or even the state. And the defunding of higher education at state and federal levels makes for frequent changes in administration.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The resources at UT Austin provided a great learning experience.  I had direct contact with some of the pioneers in my field on a regular basis and the research and instrumentation facilities across campus are second to none.
cons: The structure of my particular department hindered the feeling of community among my peers that I was expecting.  Compared to other departments I interacted with, ours was relatively separated and dispersed across campus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The current professor I work with is knowledge, kind and helpful. He offers the conditions I need to fulfill the project objective. He encourages me to publish papers, and give me instructions on how to proceed with the research. If he can't, he will provide other resources for me.
cons: Experience working with professors is highly dependent on the professor's personality. If the professor is not consistent in personality, he can be rude to some students, and ruin the students' career and graduation.

review_title: Austin is great, UT is a huge bureaucracy.
pros: Austin is a great town and UT is a brand name. University commands respect through athletics and football is king. President has limited power to change this.
cons: Cog in the machine place, even for faculty. No connection and low transparency. The campus has great facilities, but funding for support and research can be hard to come by. Another huge state university and the students are not getting a great deal. A lot of adjuncts and auxiliary faculty.

pros: I am a postdoc - I have a ton of flexibility and can often work from home.  The campus is beautiful and it is fun to be part of the University.
cons: I love the university but working with one person over the years gets old and I'm not advancing my skill set in the way I'd like.  Parking is a nightmare.  I need to be part of a team.  Where I am on campus has very limited food options.

review_title: Flexible work environment but low pay
job_title: Senior Administrative Associate in Austin, TX
pros: Friendly and intelligent coworkers; Beautiful campus; Casual office; Flexible work hours
cons: Low pay; Little to no annual merit raises; No room to advance in most departments unless someone leaves; High parking costs ($420/year), Vision and dental insurance costs seem to increase every year, even though staff gets little to no annual raise (and parking costs are proposed to increase soon, too)

review_title: Get work experience on your own if you're in graduate school.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Some faculty will support you in getting non-academic work experience if you decide that academia is not for you. Your work schedule is flexible. The first two years are like a continuation of undergrad.
cons: Most faculty will discourage you from getting any non-academic work experience. You will lose 5 years of potential wages and career building. You will work extremely hard for little compensation (~$25k-$30k per year) or benefit. What matters in the non-academic workforce is what you can do, not what you know or your degree.

pros: The work is interesting. The campus is pretty. My boss is cool and I do all my work without supervision. The equipment and software I use are all provided by the university. As part of my job, I attend different classes on campus and learn a lot of different things I wouldn't otherwise have the opportunity to learn. I mostly set my own schedule and choose the classes I want to cover.
cons: My job is only a part-time position, which is too bad, because I would work there full-time if i could. It'd also be great to get benefits, but again, it's just a part-time position.

review_title: University of Texas at Austin - A Brief Review
pros:
Get to work with some great, positive people.
Depending on immediate supervisors and management, there is the ability to tailor your workday hours around the particular needs of your department/program.
Work can be extremely challenging, requiring the development and usage of a number of skills beyond just basic clerical/administrative.
Learning resources, free to employees, to provide training and career development that can be accessed anywhere.
Work/Life balance is pretty good (at least for the given position).
cons:
Continued campus expansion makes the inexpensive parking options and spots even more of a challenge to utilize and find.
Depending on economic conditions, pay raises can take quite some time.

pros:
A few weeks after graduation (May 2012)I was contacted by a former professor to work on a research proposal.  Basically, my job was to look up information about a certain genetic disorder and follow leads on potential causes.  

It was a great experience.  Not only was I working the summer right after graduation for a good salary, but I got to hone my research experience in the process.  I also got to develop a great relationship with this professor, who's recommendation helped me land a research job back home.

The hiring and pay process was relatively painless
cons: I have nothing to complain about

review_title: Good place to get your graduate degree
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Great Campus - Large Beautiful buildings and well maintained grounds. The academic resources here are pretty incredible. Access to most scholarly publications in science and engineering along with TACC which has one of the top super computers in the world.
cons: Mostly depends on your department and professor. Bureaucracy affects pretty much everyone negatively, student fees can be high and seemingly unnecessary, particularly with  transcripts which cost $20 each now whereas at many other schools they are free.

review_title: A great opportunity to make an impact without it consuming your life
pros: The University of Texas was really flexible in working hours, as I was able to set up my office hours relative to my course schedule. I was allowed to work the majority of my hours (preparing for discussion sections and grading work) from home. Pay was amazing relative to hours worked
cons: There wasn't anything bad that I can think of during my time working as a Teaching Assistant. I suppose the only downside of the experience was having to look for another position every semester since a lot of courses have different professors every semester.

review_title: I have had a wonderful graduate student experience, with good facilities, faculty and funding opportunities.
job_title: Graduate Student (Behavioral Neuroscience) in Austin, TX
pros: Austin is a fun city. The faculty are laid back but productive. Great collaborative environment. Many labs are well-funded, allowing for more freedom to design and carry out your own research projects (as opposed to sticking with pre designed funded research projects).
cons: Too many neuroscience graduate students. The job market is too small for the number of training neuroscience students. The pay is average compared to similar graduate programs, but overall seems too little for the overall workload.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Austin, TX
pros: UT is a great place to work at because as a postdoc even if you don't earn much, at least the city is affordable and fun.  Obviously, the tricky part is picking a good lab.  Once that's settled, it's an excellent place to do research and have a good quality family life :)  Compared to the Bay Area (CA), this place doesn't make you feel like you are in a rat race.
cons: If you want to move into the biotech industry, you will feel isolated with limited opportunity since Austin doesn't have great employment in the biotech sector.

review_title: Good School, but could improve in many areas
pros: It is a good school and there is lots to do in Austin. There are good restaurants around campus and the people are generally friendly.
cons: While there are a few people to help post-docs in the college of natural sciences, overall the school is lacking in resources and training to produce successful scientists.  They rely completely on the busy faculty to train and mould productive scientists.

pros: This is a job with a lot of freedom. You get to create and deliver your own class.
cons: It seems like virtually no one is interested in education; not the students, not the supervisors, not the department. So it is easy to become jaded and come the belief that it is a lot of wasted effort.

pros: You get to work with the brightest and talented people. There is such great potential to learn and encouragement to grow in your field and academic career. Bosses are usually flexible with hours and understanding.
cons: Access to the J.J. Pickle complex can be a pain sometimes because it is so far from campus. Coordinating classes and time on campus versus the facility can be hard, especially with growing traffic. Compensation and resources are so variable depending on the project.

pros:
- Lots of opportunities to make connections
- Cool research and smart people
- Depending on your lab, you'll have a great time
- Great place for post docs
- Only applies to my department, but the administration was great!! Very helpful group of people.
cons:
- Depending on your lab, you may have a TERRIBLE time
- This is academia; if you're low on the food chain, the pay will reflect that.

pros:
*Fairly flexible schedule (in terms of scheduling around classes) 
*On campus, which is convenient
cons:
*Pay for the amount of work they want you do is not worth it
*if you drive, you have to pay for parking to go to work

review_title: Great place to rise to the top, but a lot of politics
job_title: Chemistry Graduate Student in Austin, TX
pros: Bright colleagues, great facilities, good networking, many inter-disciplinary opportunities (depending on your lab), good reputation, Austin is a nice city
