cons: Stipend is lower than other universities I applied to (but is manageable, especially since there are no state income taxes), dog-eat-dog competition in some of the labs (this really depends on which PI you choose), a lot of department politics (especially in the inorganic chemistry division; the other divisions are okay), the PIs have huge egos (but this is probably endemic to academia)

review_title: Great Place to do a PhD.
pros: UT Austin has all the resources a student could want; great researchers, great facilities, great environment.  There is also a lot to do at the university and in Austin.  At the math department, the staff was very efficient and helpful.  The workload can be large for a math TA when teaching calculus.  This last is not as bad as it seems, though; one learns to teach.
cons: Very few cons.  I do not remember anything that bothered me to much.  As mentioned above, sometimes the workload can seem large. specially at the beginning.

review_title: Good place to work  Chances to move up are frequently provided
pros:
It's fun working on most college campuses. Most of the time, you'll find very agreeable bosses
at UT since everyone is trying to keep the mood light while working hard.
cons:
Depending on your job, there can be some boring repetition. But all you need to do is stay put
for a while and then seek a different position.   Good place overall!

review_title: ITS Applications at the University of Texas
pros: Its a challenging place to work with seriously dedicated smart people. The department is highly professional and competent, customer service is very important, and they are always trying to make things better for the university.
cons: If you're creative, it's very frustrating. All projects move very slowly and sometimes never get implemented. The salaries are not competitive with the private sector.

pros: As a community, UT Austin Res Life staff care a lot about self-care and work life balance. They hire qualified people who invest in both their employees and their residents.
cons: There is a large amount of time involved in being an RA. It is rewarding, but certainly not without its frustrations. Sometimes RAs are asked to do a lot of extra work outside of their already busy school schedules.

review_title: Highgly dependent on the professor you work for
pros: It is great at its stated mission: "The mission of The University of Texas at Austin is to achieve excellence in the interrelated areas of undergraduate education, graduate education, research and public service. The university provides superior and comprehensive educational opportunities at the baccalaureate through doctoral and special professional educational levels."
cons:
Low pay as a graduate research assistant.
Some whimsical professors.
Some professors behave unethically towards students.
Tales of exploitation not uncommon.

pros: It's always nice to be able to take the time off that you need, and there are plenty of holidays.  Job security never hurts.
cons: The pay is not going to be equal to what you could make in a corporate environment, but it is better than most universities.  McCombs School of Business probably provides the most in ways of compensation.

review_title: Lots of fun, learning, and space to grow.
pros: The people here really care about how you're doing. Since the atmosphere is so relaxed, you can advance at your own pace with the guidance of others. Also, you'll constantly being meeting new people, learning social skills that can be applicable in many other fields, and finding out how many world-class resources you have access to.
cons: You must reapply for the position if you want it again in the Fall. Also, some people complain about the high price you have to pay to get a parking permit.

review_title: Working at the University Unions will positively change your career aspirations and motivations.
pros: Great leadership opportunities. Mentors are lined around the block to help you achieve your goals.
cons: Buildings close at 3:00am in the morning. If you are uncertain about your safety going home at that hour then never requests those shifts. On the plus side, UTPD does provide courtesy escorts to cars, buses, and other locations near campus. All you have to do is call them and they will send an officer.

job_title: Senior Information Technology Manager in Austin, TX
pros: UT is fairly stable. There is an emphasis on faculty and research. Many departments are cash strapped but some have plenty of funding. The central ITS department is very well run.  The campus security officer is brilliant, as is the senior leadership in the networking group.  Leadership is fairly solid at the VP and AVP levels.  Below that it depends on the department.  It's not common to work weekends, which is nice. But that depends on the department.  UT has a lot of smart and friendly people.  Over time it gets to be a comfortable family.  UT is somewhat insulated from wild economic shifts.  However, Austin in general has been growing so much it also has been insulated from downturns in recent years.  Salaries are not very competitive with the private sector, in my opinion.  UT Austin is a fantastic organization that is quite excellent at delivering a high-value education for a very competitive price.  I'm proud that I help deliver that world-class growing experience for future leaders.
cons: Technically speaking, UT is a collection of many small systems that coordinate beautifully to run a large operation.  However, this approach has led to growing pains and disparate systems.  An over-arching initiative to integrate shared services on campus in conjunction with a total replacement of the legacy mainframe and web environments have cause a great deal of frustration as the University works to bring in the new and remove the old.  For skilled workers, this is a great opportunity.  For legacy employees, it means integrating or moving out. It's fairly easy to get pigeon-holed in a particular department for years.  Moving around is not very easy.  If you are with a large department, it's easier to move within that department.  Parking is about $400 a year for garage access-- but there's a long waiting list.

pros: The people who work in the International Office are great to be around, the atmosphere is relaxed, but it's very conducive to being productive. The work load varies, but it's enough to keep you busy without feeling too stressed. Also, you meet interesting people from all over the world - how cool!
cons: I can't really think of any cons, the pay is so-so but it's a university job. No complaints from me! Except that the building is a bit far from campus. The air conditioning sometimes is not that great, but I'm really nitpicking there.

review_title: My experience as a part-time student worker in the UT IT department
job_title: Desktop Support Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: A lot of opportunities to take on projects and responsibilities as a student, flexible schedule, school holidays, opportunities to learn about IT! I personally have had some of the best managers that I bet I may ever have. Coworkers are friendly and will help you out if you have questions.
cons: my department is undergoing a lot of growing pains, since we're expanding. The department is still relatively new and is working on standardizing processes, so sometimes a process may seem vague.

review_title: Great place to work as a scientist
pros: interesting problems, access to an amazing library and resources (probably the best managed computer network I have seen), great people and collaborative environment, a great place to find and explore new ideas
cons: compensation is less than industry, but that is to be expected at a state university. not a con of UT in particular, but one has to compete for funding every year or so ("soft-money")

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: I love the great benefits, like State of Texas employee health insurance and lots of vacation time. Also the campus is beautiful, the environment is friendly, and usually you can have a flexible work schedule. And there seems to be a lot of employee programs to take advantage of, from career development seminars to quit smoking programs.
cons: The Departmental politics can be very stressful. Also, the low numbers of female tenured professors is a little distressing. Office space is always at a premium, so don't expect a lot of private work space.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The grounds were beautiful, and the labs were updated and had new technology. Machines were always available to work on, so I never felt like my work was hindered by a lack of resources. I loved my lab mates.
cons:
There is no such thing as vacation time, or sick time. In fact, it's not even written that they're required to give it to us in the handbook/contracts, and PI's make sure you know that. I was made to feel guilty any time I took even a day off. This even happened when I finally defended and wanted to take 2 weeks off before I archived my samples and left. 
You are constantly made to feel like you aren't working hard enough if you aren't working more than 40 hours/week or don't come in on the weekends/nights. I felt stressed the entire 5 years I was there. Almost everyone I knew there was either on some sort of anti-depressant, seeing a therapist, or drinking a lot. I wanted to rush through my graduate work just to finish as soon as possible so I could get out.
They barely pay you anything for a stipend, then expect you to somehow cough up a few thousand/year for "tuition tax" that you'll never see again in your tax return. The stipend is not even close to the national average.

pros: Supportive work environment. Good medical benefits especially for employee only coverage. Additional time off during the holidays is always a plus. Because it is a large university the opportunities for advancement are good but usually means changing departments which might be considered a con.
cons: Can go years without a pay raise. Parking is difficult/expensive on main campus. Advancement usually means moving to another department.

review_title: Still a great place to work - but a lot of turmoil
job_title: Human Resources Assistant III in Austin, TX
pros: Great benefits, though they seem slightly reduced every year. The fringe benefits, access to classes, employee discounts etc., make it worth the trouble.
cons: Just as in private sector, there have been lay-offs, re-orgs, RIF's etc. These things aren't always communicated well. There's a constant cycle of "let's decentralize to save money" followed by, "let's centralize everything to save money."  That gets old pretty quickly but the U never seems to learn what works.

pros: Excellent work-life balance, lots of opportunities to learn new things, take courses and become involved in the community.  Exciting expansion of the medical research and cancer research community.
cons: Grossly under-paid.  Recruiters offer 2-3X the salary I currently make.  Makes staying a very touch decision...pay student loans and leave UT or stay, and never pay off your student loans?!

review_title: Super flexible hours and very understandable on your needs because they know you are a student
pros: I enjoyed teaching at Sanger. The staffs are very nice people and they understand that we are also students, so we are not required to work during finals. They are always on the tutor's side when it comes to conflict with your tutees. They are also reasonable people.
cons: Pay is ok. If you are really good at teaching, you probably can get paid more at other tutoring places, but I still chose Sanger because the location is on campus and they treat you well.

review_title: Working as a staff member at UT Austin
job_title: Senior Academic Advisor in Austin, TX
pros: Supportive colleagues, vibrant environment, great benefits, excellent work-life balance, rewarding work
cons: staff are the third tier behind faculty and students, low salary and no guarantee of annual increases despite increasing workloads, no clear career advancement paths for staff, must pay $400+ annually to park in the garage then have to hike into campus to my office location

review_title: Aerospace Research Assistant - Excellent growth experience
pros: Research assistantships offer an excellent opportunity to put the skills learned in the classroom into practice.  Because you will likely be working on the cutting edge, things tend to be very academic in nature and, as opposed to say, a summer internship with a tech conglomerate, may not follow the common "I took 2 years of calculus but have never had to use it on the job" trajectory.  Additionally, because research is often 75% "let's figure out how to set up this experiment / project and get the results", 25% "analyze in write about the results", and research labs tend to have a lot of work to go around for not enough people, you'll find yourself frequently learning new skills that you would never have gained with your given curriculum.  For example, I worked on a project focusing on improving GPS/GNSS, but as a result of development ended up learning about data communications / networking, working with poorly documented but highly useful off-the-shelf components, and servers.  While a lot of research assistantships begin as unpaid, professors often reward handwork and dedication by transitioning you into a part-time paid position with a competitive hourly wage.  Lastly, a lot of labs allow you to work whenever you choose - 9-5, early mornings, or late nights - and are well aware of your academic needs and requirements.
cons:
- Research assistantships generally start off as unpaid positions, and even when they are paid, it may be for only a fraction of the amount of time you actually need to work (they can offer your 10hrs a week pay at $18/hr, but you often need to spend more like 30hrs in the lab to deliver)
- Lax work environment of some labs may not be appropriate for everyone (say, if you have trouble finding motivation to work when you know that know one is expecting you at a given time - which is nothing to be ashamed of, just something to be aware of)

pros: Flexible time schedules are really good and help you stay up to date with your school work as well
cons: No downsides at all surprisingly.No downsides at all surprisingly . No downsides at all surprisingly . No downsides at all surprisingly . No downsides at all surprisingly . No downsides at all surprisingly .No downsides at all surprisingly

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Flexibility with work schedule, but ensure that the professor supervising the course is reasonable. I recommend asking past TAs on their opinion before committing to any course. There are some great faculty members here that have a passion for pedagogy and are willing to mentor you to become a better teacher yourself.
cons: Work hours can be long especially when the budgets for your course are cut. A lack of TAs for a course increase your workload dramatically. Students can come off as entitled, but firm and consistent rules take care of all but the most problematic students.

pros:
UT is a nice campus. My department has been very good to work in. I have stayed in the same department for 6-1/2 years (actually 7 years, but temp work hours are prorated into state service and don't count as full time). Very nice that UTemp work hours count towards state service once you are hired full-time. Longevitiy pay after two years. Minimum 7 day holiday for Christmas/New Year's. Increased holiday hours earned over time, holiday and sick rolls over year to year, with some limitations, unlimited for sick. Very good benefits, especially if you are single. 
If you are in a good department with a good supervisor, then you can do well. I have been blessed to have a good supervisor the past 3 years, which has provided opportunity for me to promote twice in those 3 years.
cons:
"Merit" raises are based on budget and what the top echelon wants to pass down. It is usually 2-3%. Sometimes the "raise" is only a bonus, so it doesn't increase your salary for the next "raise". My current pay grade stinks, the maximum I could make is about mid-$40k, and I can't earn any overtime only comp time. 
It's hard to get into other departments on campus. Once you are in a department there are limited opportunities unless someone retires. 
Work from home is unheard of in my department, and I don't know anyone outside of IT that has the opportunity to work from home. We had flex work schedule (10 hrs vs. 8 hrs) available one summer. 
Pay for parking, and parking is bad if you come into work late. Expect to be at work by 8 a.m. for parking. "A" staff parking has gotten slimmer since I've worked here.

review_title: Great place to work but zero opportunity for advancement
pros:
Lucky enough to have a wonderful boss - v supportive and hands-off but great at re-directing me when needed.
Had an office to myself even though not a manager, due to being housed in an old building.
Grew some sustainability initiatives which gained teeth and support from many depts.
cons:
No opportunity for advancement in the dept I was in (EHS).
Dept head was not very effective and replacement of him after retirement took over 1.5 years.  Pretty stodgy HR movement when it comes to hiring.

pros: I have had wonderful colleagues and the occasional exceptional supervisor. I love the campus, and most of the students are wonderful. I enjoy the school spirit and working with impressive students. I love the actual work involved with the jobs I've held here.
cons: Pay is terrible. I have been promised raises/promotions and had them cancelled multiple times. Upper management has no clue what's happening on the ground level, and they are (generally) more concerned with 4 year graduation rates and rankings than ensuring student and staff needs are met:  While students are struggling to get the classes they need and an appointment with a staff member, staff members struggle to serve students with outdated and choppy home-grown resources that make it challenging to do their jobs efficiently. Because UT is so large, it's only natural that there would be some disconnect between different areas of the University, but even within a single college or office it seems that deans, faculty, student services, and IT are out of touch with each other.

pros: The University of Texas employees are considered state employees and are members of the Teacher Retirement System of Texas. Full-time employees receive full healthcare coverage and are highly rewarded for longevity through merit raises, longevity pay, and increases in paid time off.
cons: Starting salaries at the University of Texas are not very high, and you have to worry about the bureaucracy that is higher education. In our college, the dean has the final say, even though he does not know what is going on in each department and does not care to understand.

pros: My specific supervisor is excellent and allows for a lot of flexibility and I enjoy my particular team (this is not a common sentiment across all units). People I work with are passionate, creative, and have incredible life experiences. UT also has great health benefits.
cons: Leadership is not transparent. Staff are not able to excel or be their full creative selves because decisions bottleneck at the top. There is little opportunity for upward mobility (unless you go to another department on campus)

pros: You get to work with some of the most talented and brilliant people, and there are large opportunities to learn and grow a career in research and/or academia. Hours are flexible and bosses are very understanding.
cons: The research facility is farther away from campus, and the shuttle is not as reliable as I would have liked it to be (J. J. Pickle). Resources can be limited but is variable to as which project you are working on.

pros: It's a great experience while working on your graduate degree, but TA positions vary greatly even within each faculty. The tuition reduction is also a great help.
cons: The salary is fairly low, unless you add both the tuition reduction and your salary together. My personal experience wasn't a traditional TA position and I had little hands on teaching. Also, some TA positions expect close to 40 hours of work per week, which is hard while completing your Master's or PhD.

pros: World class institution with great faculty.  Pretty good time off policy and other perks. Many collaborative opportunities if you work in the science/research field.
cons: Parking is quite horrible around campus, must arrive quite early to get a decent parking spot.  Also employees are required to pay for parking, and it's not so cheap. Also, traffic is starting to get bad around the area and it is not cheap to live nearby.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The health insurance is excellent and Austin is an awesome city to live in. With the salary UT pays you, you can live pretty comfortably if you find some place with cheap rent.
cons: UT doesn't increase your wages to match cost of living increases. You have to live pretty far from campus in order to live comfortably and UT has cut a lot of the shuttle service to places far from campus.

pros: lots of homework time, supervisor works with your class schedule, lots of tasks but not very hard to complete, sometimes there is food
cons: none, but might get odd hours, it can get really boring if you dont find anything to do.  Don't particularly like shelving books that are very low on the shelf but oh well, still have to live with it

pros: Flexible hours, safe campus, great benefits
cons: Pay varies greatly depending on the lab you work in.  Hours and expectations very greatly depending on Project Investigator (PI).  There aren't any 'hard rules' and PIs are allowed to make whatever expectations they choose, whether reasonable or not.

pros: Job stability, substantial benefits, work outdoors with minimal supervision, lenient with time off requests, a "family" work culture environment, fun managers. Work shirts, pants & steel toed boots paid for by UT. 40 hour week, Mon-Fri, weekends off.
cons: Low pay with little room for advancement.  No salary increases, only one-time merit bonuses of 2-4 %. work is repetitive and unchallenging.  easy to become apathetic.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Health insurance is phenomenal! if you are working in a department that you are actually passionate about, this is an amazing place to work.
cons: Watch out for interviews. They tend to take their entry level jobs WAY too seriously. In my opinion, they should be more inclined to TEACH you if you are at that level. I mean... it is a university.

review_title: Great place to learn, but not to advance
job_title: Study Abroad Program Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: Everyone generally likes the higher education environment as a place to grow and learn. UT attracts some great people because of its name, so my colleagues are pretty great, with unique experiences and perspectives. The students at UT are really great to work with and supervise, with rare exceptions. I have supervised quite a few in the office and they have almost all amazed me with their accomplishments. The International Office is good at what it does, by many measures, and has a long track record of successful programming in the International Office. It stands out among peer institutions and in the field of international education. Leadership tries to do their best for staff with budget constraints and workload (see below).
cons: Everyone in education always jokes that the pay is bad, so you are there because you love it. But that is really the case in Texas. The pay is very low relative to comparable positions, and while UT tries to add other benefits, they aren't that competitive to make up for the salary, especially with rising inflation, cost of living in Austin, and the cost of insurance. There also aren't really any advancement strategies for entry or mid-level positions. Bureaucracy, state legislation, and budget constraints (real or constructed) result in no pay raises and little to no professional development. The International Office is in better shape than most other academic departments on campus, though, since it can utilize fees from programming. Leadership tends to get mired in the mindset that there are too many battles to fight, and improving salaries for staff is too hard a battle to fight with the university. The result is burn-out among staff and a revolving door, especially among entry-level staff. There seems to be relatively little strategic planning. It tries to justify what it does based on data, instead of planning what it should do based on data. When I applied, I made it clear that I was interested in growing with the organization and asked about prospects for advancement, and was mislead to think it was a possibility to advance. Later I discovered that in order to advance to a mid-management position, I needed to have had supervised full-level staff in my previous work experience. This essentially creates a barrier for any entry-level staff to grow, and means that they have to go somewhere else. The office loses their expertise and knowledge, and create perpetual problems with team workload and continually needing to train new staff. HR practices assume that previous experience in terms of years yields better candidates. It's like this in most places I have seen across higher education, but a better system of applying and interviewing that addresses fit and incorporates areas the candidate can grow and contribute.

review_title: Working for UT-Austin was overall a fun and worthwhile experience, though a little daunting and emotionally draining.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Working as a TA provides a healthy tuition rebate and in state tuition if you work 20 hours or more.
cons: Working as a TA, you are often on call running odd errands and fulfilling strange requests at a moments notice. You also frequently end up acting as a liaison between the professor and the students comforting someone who can't seem to bring their grade up or breaking bad news to more obstinate and irate students.

pros: Health, vision, dental benefits, time-off policies are all great. There are some opportunities for advancement and promotion in the right areas.  Good opportunities to network and train in your area. Culture is forward thinking.
cons: Some people are very arrogant.  Salaries are stagnant sometimes and not as competitive as they could be in some areas.  When the legislature is in session salaries really freeze up.  Legislative restrictions impede some cultural initiatives.  Lots of red tape when trying to get things done but it is a government entity so that is expected. Parking.

pros: Very convenient to work their as a student. I worked hourly so I could get stuff done in between or after classes. Flexible work hours although it depends on your supervisor.
cons: Obviously there is little opportunity to advance in a career. Just temporary work, so I don't really have any explicit negatives to list. I'd say this is just ideal work for a student.

review_title: Good for a year, then move on.
pros: Freedom to try new things, learn new CMS, languages, etc. The benefits are fantastic- you need a seatbelt during the orientation to listen to what they offer you. You don't pay hardly anything for any medical bill and retirement plan is awesome. Work at your own pace- deadlines mean nothing here.
cons:
I can't stress enough how bad the IT is. They are running ten year old machines on safe mode for security reasons and makes it nearly impossible to expect anything to work on them. You cannot troubleshoot issues because nobody else in the world has these problems and furthermore you are restricted from accessing anything that would give you clues as to what's wrong- and rightly so- but those who hold the keys either don't care or are incompetent and do not respond to calls or emails. They do not have cPanel. phpMyadmin is available, but has a very low memory limit and makes importing/exporting db's impossible. The workarounds that IT provides are ludicrous and they act like you're the crazy one when you call them out. 

There is also no accountability for them since there is not one group. There is a small 1-3 person IT team for each college and a small "central" group. They do not communicate or work together and so they are all weak, indecisive, and incapable of providing a good product or good support. 

I have no clue why they don't outsource IT which would provide security, timeliness, support, and access to those who's jobs depend on it. I have no idea why they don't either hire people or buy new machines. They have to meet about the smallest decision and as a result nothing gets accomplished.

We had websites in a CMS that couldn't install updates or plugins because of security restrictions. It took weeks to get a database and a folder on their server, clients were constantly mad that their sites wouldn't work and what's worse is there was nothing you could do to fix it, just constantly waiting on someone that had no interest in helping.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The work as a Teaching Assistant is quite demanding alongside your regular coursework, but at the same time it is a huge learning and interaction opportunity.
cons: Work can get hectic at times, if you are doing a part time for two courses to make it a full time. Would not recommend in case you are taking high demanding courses.

review_title: College of Pharmacy division of pharmacology and toxicology
pros: on the whole the University is great and its located in a great city. the toxicology side of the division within the college of pharmacy is doing some great cancer related research.
cons: The pharmacology portion of the division within the college is poorly directed and the primary investigators with a few exceptions don't seem to really care about how their portion of the division is viewed. they don't seem to care about their students.

review_title: Very nice people, slow turnaround on projects
pros: The nicest people I've worked with, no matter what area of the University (my position has broad scope).  Great benefits and flexible work hours.
cons: Since you're essentially working for the state government, you are at its mercy as far as what budgets allow which ultimately affects your rate of pay.  Also, expect to pay for your own parking (mine $400 annually) which will likely be a 15-20 minute walk if you work inside campus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Depending on the department, the graduate research assistantship paid very well compared to other universities, including decent health insurance and benefits.
cons: Depending on the department, professors are incredibly busy and not always available for advice. Also, the ratio of workload to pay isn't always justified as students will spend long and late hours on campus.

review_title: Not sure it was worth it.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Decent employee insurance. Good location. No state income tax.
cons: Even if you're fully-funded and think a graduate program is where you wanna be, you should know that, as a graduate employee, you're not paying into FICA (federal exemption, not just Texas) or unemployment insurance. So years spent working full time as a GRA or GTA will not count toward any of the standard societal protections to which adult humans are typically entitled in through basically any other full time employment.

review_title: No incentive to perform, very reactive, and unwilling to change
pros: Time off, benefits, and campus environment. Proximity to students, and working with and for them provided a unique work environment that provided energy and enthusiasm.
cons: salary, growth, advancement, incompetent management, political circles. Constantly ran into situations that existed only because it was the way it had always been done, while still recognizing that it was ridiculous. Ole boys club and you needed to be one. Felt very much like you belonged to a specific class, and should expect to be treated, and managed as such.

job_title: Research Engineering/Scientist Associate III in Austin, TX
pros: I had great colleagues in the departments I worked and a great selection of top notch seminars to attend.  The University provides a good benefits package for staff, which is very helpful.
cons: This is a state university with all the bureaucracy that comes with it.  In scientific research, this can sometimes slow things down.

pros: University of Texas at Austin is a great place to learn. Lots of companies select their employees from here. A high quality university with lots of opportunities.
cons: Since this is s state university sometimes there are lots of paper work has to be done for simple things which could be a hassle.

review_title: As an Undergrad Research Assistant I can apply abstract classroom knowledge & finally understand its practical relevance
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Gaining research experience while still an undergraduate; connect with the companies participating in the cutting-edge projects in my industry; getting early insight about which topics actually interest me personally; working alongside some of the brightest minds in the entire field, worldwide; being credited with co-authorship of research publications - an excellent resume-builder. Also, my schedule couldn't be more flexible.
cons: State legislation limits my pay scale, regardless of my performance.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
Lots of opportunities in hard science fields
Good user facilities in CNM/FNT
Relatively low cost of living (no state income tax)
Austin
cons:
If you're on fellowship like the NSF, you don't get the good employee health insurance.
Rumor is some Deans aren't putting funds towards support Tier 1 research like they should. 
Great research faculty doesn't always translate to great instructors.

review_title: I loved my job at one of the undergraduate offices at UT.
pros: There were flexible hours that allowed me to keep up with school and have a part-time job at the same time.
cons: It would get really busy at the office I worked at sometimes, and I felt there weren't enough of us to handle the load. There was also a really high turnover of higher level employees. I personally saw 3 different people work the same full-time position as my direct boss in the year and a half I worked my job.

job_title: ITS Point People in Austin, TX
pros: Close to all my classes, hours are extremely flexible, I've learned a little bit about the software industry by talking to the programmers.
cons: The pay isn't the best, and sometimes you're given way too many tasks to be able to do in a normal work period.

review_title: Great place to work, but not necessarily a place for advancement
pros: The pay is very good for higher education, and employees are treated well. Your colleagues will respect you for what you can do, regardless of your age or background.
cons: It doesn't seem like there is much room for movement within the system in terms of career progression. Where you are hired is pretty much where you will stay, with few exceptions. I think this applies equally for staff and faculty.

review_title: It's been a great place to work, but the salary has not kept up with the cost of living in Austin.
pros: Wonderful, intelligent people, job security, time-off over the holidays, and decent benefits.
cons: Low salaries, no increase in YEARS due to budget constraints (and apparently it is not getting any better for the foreseeable future), not a lot of room for upward mobility or career growth depending on dept.

job_title: Senior Administrative Associate in Austin, TX
pros: You really can't beat the solid benefits package they offer at The University of Texas at Austin.  Having access to all the facilities that a large campus like UT provides is also a big plus.
cons: Not gonna lie, you won't make serious money at UT unless you're in very particular fields.  This is also the State of Texas, an enormous bureaucracy, which often makes getting things done in a timely fashion difficult.

review_title: Student Library Assistant - School of Social Work
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Incredibly laid-back environment, the job can be fulfilling when assisting professors, students, and guest speakers with technical issues.
cons: A lot of down time. Sometimes the Learning Resources Center can go hours without receiving a visitor.  Lack of funding for better aesthetics.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: It actually depends on who you are working with and which course you are taking in charge of. However, overall, it is a great chance to learn not only the knowledge regarding the class materials itself but also experience classroom environment in the tutor's perspective. If you are thinking remaining in school and become a professor, it will be really helpful.
cons: As mentioned above, it really depends on who you are working for. I know some graduate teaching assistants are abused and spend too much time on grading etc,. Good luck!

pros: Had the opportunity to teach my own class and develop instructional materials. My department already had a very well designed syllabus for the class, we had regular section meetings and my supervisor was very supportive.
cons: I was not very flexible because I had to follow a strictly outlined syllabus. For my students, this unfortunately created an excessive and unnecessary workload.

pros: The office is relatively quiet and the small work environment meant that I could really build work relationships with my supervisors. Because of this, they also allowed me to work on my graphic design skills to help with their promotional materials. I was given freedom and autonomy over my creative work.
cons: Sometimes the lack of student or faculty activity around the office made for a solo environment. I would have liked to have more face to face interactions with people coming in and out of the office.

pros: sufficient funding to work on things you want, work-life balance is okay, training is good, average time-off policies, weather is good, good support from different departments
cons: office culture is very beauracratic, which is very typical of government organizations, so expect that things move forward very slow. Everything works good in general except when it doesn't.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
Great freedom in planning own courses
Intellectually stimulating, teaching very smart students
Excellent work environment, flexible hours
Vibrant campus life
cons: Amount of work can be disproportionate to compensation. Similar institutions across the country pay their doctoral candidates much better, and Austin is getting a very expensive city - it is almost impossible to afford living near campus with current levels of compensation.

review_title: It's not bad if you don't mind all the red tape
job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: I had 2 different positions on campus and I had great co-workers and bosses in both positions and made some good friends while I was there. Your health insurance is subsidized by the University, they match your retirement contributions, you can enroll in classes for free after you work there for a year, free therapy (on campus), various other "perks" for working for the government.
cons: Lots of budget cuts, downsizing, and bureaucratic red tape to deal with. Also, parking sucks.

review_title: Good place to get your part time job
pros: I've been working as a learning assistant in the Physics department for more than a year. It is really enjoyable. The instructors are nice and it's a great experience to know more students and to improve my communication skills.
cons: If you cannot find a good instructor, you might have difficulties working with the instructor. Some physics instructors are not very nice and they might not be good at communication with others. So, it is tough sometimes to get along with them.

pros: Great benefits especially for people with families, good salary for the job. Incredible analytical resources for conducting research. Most professors have open doors, so there are many opportunities to collaborate.
cons: It's hard to find an affordable place within a few miles of campus: your choices are to pay sky-high rent or sacrifice your free time commuting.

review_title: Good place to work while going to school
pros: Grading is a good way to make extra cash. You can do it on your own time from anywhere, as long as you have wi-fi.
cons: Some of the submissions are low quality and hard to grade. Also, the pay for this job fairly low and I can only claim 6 hours of work per week.

pros: Very forward thinking VP, Director, and team lead.
cons: That's very hard to imagine at this point. But, there are some tunnels and steam pipes one has to walk into making it easier to get hurt if you don't watch your step.

pros: There are many intangible benefits that come along with employment at a large university. The affiliation alone is a big perk. There is a sense of pride that comes from working for an organization that so many wish to be part of.
cons: The pay is considerably less than the going market rate in some professions on campus. In addition, the budget cuts leave a grim outlook for future compensation.

review_title: A lot of work with very flexible times
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: I really like that I can work whenever I want to, I can come in pretty late as long as I stay long enough to get the work done. I can structure my day however I want to. Research facilities are great and a lot of very good faculty.
cons: A lot of work and sometimes it is expected to come in at the weekends. Pay definitely doesn't make up for the hours, but I can take classes and get a degree.

review_title: Supportive staff, flexible hours, and an enriching experience.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
-In the labs the hours are very relaxed and the graduate researchers understand how busy life can be
-Payment process is easy and pay periods are clearly defined
-Coworkers are very congenial and helpful and adept at explaining the experiments and scientific theory behind them
cons:
-It takes forever to receive the money from a pay period
-Certain safety training sessions are redundant and seem pretty unnecessary considering how common sensical they are
-Occasionally there's nothing to do so it can get a little boring

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: My part time position had very flexible hours and I had the ability to structure work hours around my class schedule.  In my case it also lead to a research project.
cons: Unless you are student, I would not recommend this position.  This type of job is targeted towards students trying to study for classes and make a little money on the side.

review_title: Good Place to study and do research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The city of Austin has a lot of fun. The faculty here are knowledgeable and very creative. The facility here are great to make things happen. The peer students are nice and helpful.
cons: The parking places are very limited. Taking the A parking permit as a example, you need to arrive at 6:30 to make sure you can park the car in the A parking lot.

pros: I worked as graduate research assistant in University of Texas at Austin for 5 and a half years. I liked warm weather in Austin and very friendly and liberal environment.
cons: The salary is not much compared to other jobs. But as a graduate student, the money is enough to live alone. If you have other dependent, the life would be tougher.

pros: Established institution that allows for personal growth within the field you work. It has great compensation for employees and it offers flexible schedules for employees.
cons: There are limitations for professional growth, but there are networking developments that can allow for growth elsewhere within the university or the community.

job_title: Associate Director of Development in Austin, TX
pros:
Great salary
Flexible work hours
Great people to work with
cons:
High turn over in the field
A lot of travel is required; difficult to manage with young children

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: A really good program, very diverse research fields. Some big names in computational science. Their computational science group is among the top of the nation
cons: You may end up with a research you are not very interested. But you can still process a lot if the professor is the expert. Austin is a pretty cool town.

pros: Nice people on my level of employment.  Good to be on a university campus. Many opportunities to learn.
cons: Opportunities to learn but little chance to be promoted.  Employees are given a job description, told to keep to it, and then they're asked to do something beyond the job description--without increase in wages.

pros: UT is focused on innovation and works to move with the trends of the generation of students attending.
cons: Because it is a government organization, it is subject to the legislature.  Additionally, pay for staff tends to be low--but comparable to other institutions of higher education.  No paid maternity/paternity leave.

review_title: Great place to work if you get the right department.
pros: Great benefits; support of after 5 educational and life interests; casual atmosphere
cons: Political; cliquish--if you get in a good department with strong leadership, it can be a fantastic experience. However, in many departments egos run the show and disorganization and inefficiency rule the day.

pros: Extraordinary resources: libraries, research centers, faculty, students, personnel, etc. Enjoyable place to work, especially as a graduate student when you need a flexible work schedule. Since many people are "moving through" Austin, you inevitably establish a nationwide network of contacts who fondly remember their time in Texas.
cons: Depending on the department or college you work for, your pay is low though the benefits are great. Also, depending on what type of course you're assisting (lower-level vs upper), your workload may overflow the established hours.

review_title: Great place to work, watch out for yourself
pros:
Academic atmosphere -- plenty of lectures, exhibits. Staff can take one free class for credit per semester.
Good benefits
Challenging work with good support structure
cons:
Some chaos in IT. Has been trying to work it all out for years.
Pay attention to your career development because your manager won't do it for you. Can be tough to get approval for career development activities, despite published policies.
Dealing with some tough financial considerations. Partially dependent on state funding, which can vary every two years.

review_title: It has been a good experience while working through college
job_title: IT Helpdesk (Student Worker) in Austin, TX
pros: It has been a great experience to have as a student worker. My bosses have been very understanding and flexible with time off, supportive of my educational pursuits. The employees are treated with respect and help is readily available.
cons: Student positions cannot turn into full time positions, and there are no benefits for student workers.

review_title: Employment as a graduate student at UT was very helpful for completing my degree.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
Some of the pros include:
-access to campus amenities (gyms, sporting events, etc)
-paid tuition and monthly stipend
-access to UT library system's publication connections
-access to seminars and other educational events
cons:
Some of the cons include:
-low level of monthly stipend is just enough for living expenses and food
-parking on campus is a pain

review_title: Graduate Student in the Life Sciences
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: UT Austin does a great job of ensuring that you are fully funded for the first year, but after that it is the responsibility of the professor whose lab you work in to pay your salary.
cons: UT has an excellent curriculum and high quality research faculty.  However, the graduation time for a PhD is very long (approximately 6-6.5 years).

review_title: An unfortunately short stint at my favorite job to date.
pros:
Note: I worked for the Department of Food and Health Services (DHFS).
- flexible
- did not inhibit my studies (I was a student while working)
- social aspect of employment is a plus
cons: - often confounded reasonings for decisions by upper management

review_title: A good place to work overall
pros:
- Diverse campus with interesting people and inspiring work
- Located in a great city
- For the most part, job security
- Retirement benefits are pretty nice
cons:
- Too much red tape 
- Concerns about potential legal repercussions often stifle innovation
- Very stratified organization, with complex decision making patterns and sometimes conflicting agendas

review_title: Great environment but limited compensation and opportunities for advancement
pros: Great location and wonderful benefits and perks.  Work is interesting and you meet lots of great people.
cons: Difficult to take advantage of training opportunities since the work is 8-5.   Advancement is not discussed.   Increasing dissatisfaction with current staff due to layoffs.   Salaries are generally below what students make when they graduate.  Increasing bureaucracy as the university tries to centralize operations.

pros:
As a TA it was great to have medical benefits, tuition reduction, and a monthly stipend.
Great way to network and gain experience within a higher education setting.
cons: TAs do not accrue sick leave or vacation time. This often becomes a struggle when you or your child become ill and are expected to make up missed hours.

pros: wonderful environment, great benefits and it is in Austin, TX - what else do you need. it is a large university so there are plus and minus with this situaion.
cons: Some constraints of being a sate employee, but it is mandated by state legislation - so what can you do ? just  a function of the territory.

review_title: I look forward to going to work everyday.
pros: Paid to be at a university. Benefits. Non-work life is important to supervisors. General happiness of fellow employees is relatively high. Room for growth and improvement. Consistent environment. All national holidays paid. Low-stress. Potential for free credited courses.
cons: Bureaucratic. State-funded (state legislators control large chunk of budget). Change is slow in many aspects. I really can't think of any other cons at the moment.

job_title: Clinical Nurse Educator in Austin, TX
pros: Association with a prestigious organization, access to full spectrum of online research databases, opportunity to work with motivated students from varied backgrounds.
cons: Lower salary compared with other similar institutions, rigid bureaucracy, no paid amenities (parking), outdated offices / facilities

pros: I enjoy working with children. We can learn from them just as they can learn from an adult
cons: Learning to get children to get along. Teaching them what is the value of friendship is

review_title: Great place for students to work!
job_title: Student Technical Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Hours are adjusted around your schedule. Usually a laid-back job; you have to be motivated and willing to help when technical problems arise, but there are many times that you're just on standby and you can work on homework instead.
cons: Most employees, if not everyone, have to take a 6am shift to check classrooms before classes start, everyday. Also if you're not good at talking to people or dealing with technical problems, this job might not be for you.

pros: Benefits are good compared with other companies
cons:
Too much work for a single person
Usually no lunch time
They are growing in a no organized way, what means be fixing unnecessary problems all the time
Too much "unnecessary drama" inside the institution
They are not interested in the satisfaction of the tech personnel
No  communication between any parts (medical, administrative, tech)

review_title: Works for those committed to university's mission, not for those wanting pay
pros: Lots of interesting and hard work available given the tremendous scale.  You can make a difference *if* you are willing to stick with things.  It is "efficient", which in a positive way is a challenge.
cons: Not a place to be if status/salary are drivers (unless you are faculty).  It is "efficient", which in a negative way means you are under constant economic pressures not experienced at typical business.

review_title: The University of Texas at Austin
job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
-The culture/ team work at UT is great: I love the atmosphere and the dedication of the Department of Communication Studies. An active open door policy keeps our department culture very successful and friendly.
-The Moody College of Communication at UT delivers ongoing in-depth training for both researchers and practitioners, which is helpful for my professional development in most communication areas.
cons: -Since students are only allowed to work as part-time staff on campus, the pay was not very competitive.

pros: Great university in an excellent town.  Great for parents as they have top-notch on-site and affordable daycare (cost scaled to employee income).
cons: Large-university bureaucracy and unavoidable state education politics.  It's a university, so if you're a PhD not interested in being a professor you'll always be something of a second-class citizen.  Parking can be a nightmare.

pros: Not many. Holidays. Students. Trees.
cons: The university does not value its employees, the top make a ridiculous amount of money and the bottom struggle to get by. People are considered expendable and treated that way.

review_title: Great place to work, great benefits, wish we'd get paid more.
pros: Great benefits, and smaller departments can be really wonderful to work for. Really great environment!
cons: The money isn't the best out there. You can get paid 10-20% more working for a private company, but the job security is hard to beat.

review_title: Orientation Advisor was a great one-time experience.
pros: Free housing, free food, great people, amazing learning experience, educational, paid well, weekends off (normally), and you got to introduce incoming freshman to the greatest school in Texas!
cons: Can be intense, long hours, strict rules, could be extremely frustrating at times, and at times I felt as if I was walking on eggshells.

pros: Working around and with some of the smartest people on Earth, in one of the best cities on Earth
cons:
Questionable ethics of senior management- lip service is paid to ethics, but compromise based on office politics is the norm
Little to no chance for advancement- most management and directorial positions are filled from outside, with requirements that would exclude internal candidates

pros: Great people and staff with a lot of opportunities for overtime.  As a work study student, this was a great way to learn work culture and how to succeed.
cons: There are no cons to working here. I had a pleasurable experience here and would recommend working here.

pros: The University of Texas is a great place to work, beautiful campus, motivated people.  It's a hotbed of smart folks!
cons: As an IT professional, it's kind of easy to get lost in the maze of issues that go along with working at a large university.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Big institution with diverse departments and specialties. Easy to build collaboration with other research groups. Good career consulting services. Fast to respond to emergencies. Flexible hours.  Great gym facilities and health services.
cons: No dental coverage as part of the benefits. Switching roles between student employee and research fellow can make insurance situation complicated. TAs are paid lower than RAs in general.

pros: Worked directly with the social media director. Work place culture was relaxed and comfortable.  Challenging projects and constant work that was flexible to college schedule.
cons: Small group of ambassadors meant filling many different shoes, which could be challenging. We could have used a bit more one on one direction/interaction with supervisors.

pros:
- Really high quality education with challenging courses.
- Wide variety of classes based around emerging tech/research.
- Many collaboration opportunities
cons:
- Extremely difficult qualifying exams for PhD students.
- General difficulties associated with grad school time commitments, etc.

job_title: Undergraduate Writing Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: Working at the Undergraduate Writing Center was an incredible experience. I grew as an instructor and developed my oral communication skills as I had to provide clear guiding questions and advice to students. A very positive work environment and great coworkers. Everyone at the UWC is committed to their work, bright, and very professional.
cons: I wish that there were more hours available for undergraduate tutors at the UWC, but that is a minor con.

job_title: Senior Placement Representative in Austin, TX
pros: As compared to salaries at most universities the pay was excellent.  It was a supportive and vibrant work community in a growing and exciting city.  If there is something going on in higher education, it's going on here.
cons: It's a big place and easy to get lost in the shuffle.  The state wide budget cuts certainly impact all that happens on campus.  Budgets tend to get bloated and the turnover rate is very low.

review_title: Great Opportunity for Future Sales job
pros: Amazing incentive base. It is perfect for an entry level sales job and getting comfortable on the phone. Great teamwork environment. You can gain better pay easy. Management is very interested in your development.
cons: Your only required to work 6 hours a week 2 days in a row and micromanagement is a little worrisome.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Good faculty and staff. Great core facilities and equipment for research. The environment is collaborative. Apart from research several opportunities to do courses beyond your department.
cons: There used to be no structured career development services for graduate students. Recently they have appointed a career advisor specifically for grad students, and are improving on that.

review_title: For an undergraduate student, an on campus job offered invaluable experience.
pros: You'll gain a new appreciation for administration and education as you see the inner workings of a top university.  Having a job while taking classes helps improve time management skills and is another way to explore your interests (a lot of different departments at UT).
cons: If not careful, you might undermine your studies.

pros: Great clients and benefits; you're in your own little city on campus!
cons: They don't promote within. They have a reputation for hiring outside then the people that have been dedicated employees for YEARS (10+) they over look and expect them to train the newbie. Not good for your self worth...and I know personally that they loose very good employees because of this practice.

pros: As an employee, you have access to thousands of staff & faculty across many disciplines in a fast-paced, challenging environment.
cons: As a state entity, UT has limited resources and all decisions come with miles of red tape. It's very difficult to  push for change when it comes to updating policies, so technologies and strategies are often out-dated. It can be an extremely repetitive environment and the salaries are not competitive until you get to the Director level positions.

job_title: Student Peer Mentor in Houston, TX
pros: It's a job where you get to see how you make a difference in someone's life. Flexible. Team work is a must.
cons: Everyone gets overwhelmed at the exact same time. When you're a peer mentor with students, you're also a student. It's difficult to stay 100% positive when even you're not feeling it and neither are the students, but that's only like one to two weeks every month and a half. Otherwise, it's pretty neat.

review_title: A great place to go to graduate school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: UT is a large university with many departments and a wide variety of research going on.  Chances are there is somebody doing work in your area of interest.
cons: There are not many downsides to UT that I can think of.  Some people don't like the hot weather in the summer.  One problem has been the lack of a medical school and associated research, but that deficiency is now being remedied.

review_title: UT is great. Austin is also a nice city to live. We have so many young people here.
pros: The work-life balance is great. Austin has so many activities. The weather and culture here in austin is great.
cons: The benefits in general is good. But the living cost in Austin keeps increasing. The salary has been fixed for a while.

review_title: Should remember that to be successful in developing innovation, should create a culture of innovation within institute
pros:
35 years of experience, global reach in over 30 countries
Strong reputation and well-formed network
Many helpful professionals with years of experience and willingness to mentor
Not just research oriented but implementers also
cons:
Even though they preach innovation, office culture feels quite dated
Sit on past successes and are not proactive in remaining part of the innovation conversation
Poor upper management, don't create an environment where young employees want to

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
enough for leading an average life. Include health insurance. My supervisor is flexible and very nice.
Other facultys are available for research questions.
cons: They don't spend enough money on updating facilities. My computer only has an i3 processor and 4G memory. The salary is just enough.

job_title: Senior Technology Licensing Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: While a few individuals might have that government worker attitude, most people I dealt with were very pleasant and easy to work with.
cons: Some positions are expendable and you may be shocked one day to find out your's is. No choice given to transfer. Just happy and gainfully employed one day and gone the next.

review_title: You're paid to get a graduate degree.  How can you beat that?
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: It's an excellent academic institution, with wonder students, faculty, and staff.  The name carries weight with employers and grant reviewers.  Austin is a truly wonderful city to live in.
cons: Academia is political, like everywhere.  It can be quite warm in the summertime in Austin.  The pay, at least as a graduate student in engineering, isn't great, but you can pay your rent.

review_title: Difficult engineering program, but there are some of the brightest minds in the world here and they are my professors.
pros: Great networking opportunities and endless research. If you want to do a certain type of research or work under any specialist in a specific field - we probably have them.
cons: Very large, its easy to get lost in the sea of college students if you do not know how to find where you belong.

review_title: Can excel if you know the right people; great facilities and very professional
pros:
great bus system, students/employees ride bus for free
if you know the right people, publishing research, making UT look good in some way then you can climb
cons:
rent is sky rocketing
traffic is crazy and parking on campus is pretty pricey 
not sure about their EEO policies, there seem to be some disparities

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: This was a great place to work as a teaching assistant.  The students were there to learn and there was good support from the faculty and administration.
cons: The only negative was the large class size.  This limits ability to get to know the students and offer them the kind of help they need if they start to fall behind.

review_title: I was a learning assistant at UT.
pros: I was given a lot of responsibility and ownership over the role that I had. My instructor gave me a lot of freedom to be creative, while making sure that I didn't mess anything up. I gained a lot of valuable experience working with and for others in a productive learning environment.
cons: There was no training. The pay was a little low. There really were no significant cons to this experience. Overall great!

job_title: Electronic Technical Staff Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Friendly work environment, Good Work / Life balance, Good benefits, Good variety of work, Academic work environment, Extra vacation days, Sick days, Paid Jury Duty, Not in Downtown traffic, Research new products
cons: Lower pay than average, Slow job advancement, Hard to transfer to other departments, Short project time schedule, Old test and measurment equipment

pros: Working for the Temp Agency within the University was good. The temp positions were always challenging
cons: Sometimes the supervisors were not what they seemed to be. At times impatient, rude, biased and untruthful.

pros: I work as an IT Assistant at the UT BME Department. The people I work with area amazing and I have a very good schedule. I have gotten to learn a lot.
cons: The downsides are scarce. However having a part-time job with full-time school is pretty tough. I do have some free time to do my own work but when I'm there work comes before homework because well that's what learning time management helps you do.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: As a graduate teaching assistant, tuition is paid for.
cons: Depending on what class you TA the hours you work will be wildly different. Lab courses and very large courses generally require more than 20 hours of work a week. Try and get a grader if possible.

review_title: Cannot afforod my life in Austin anymore, love my co-workers and my job
pros: Excellent benefits, smart, interesting people on staff
cons: The pay is terrible. It has increased by 2% or less for the last 5 years, during which time Austin has become one of the nation's most expensive places to live.

pros: The University has ample opportunities for advancement and is a vibrant, fast-paced place to work, good benefits, and plenty of paid time-off.
cons: Merit raises for staff are minimal and not available every year, the parking situation leaves much to be desired (you will pay $400-$500 annually to park in a garage that is a 10-15 minute walk from your building), and the pay is not as high as private sector positions.

review_title: Good for students who is looking for some extra money and work experience
pros: The library associate jobs are mostly filled with students. The workload is not too high and the work environment is friendly. I think it is very good for students to gain some work experience here.
cons: As you may expect from a typical work-study job, the pay is not high. However, given that the workload is not too high, I think the pay is fair enough.

review_title: A large organization provides room to grow and advance
pros: Stable compensation with great benefits in a fun environment.
cons: Traditional environment makes it hard to be creative and innovation is slow to develop.  A creative thinker looking for a place to excel, should look to the private sector. Politics create barriers.

review_title: Part-time as student- Office of Survey Research
pros:
-Flexible schedule for full-time students 
-Surrounded by peers 
-Nearby campus if you're a UT student and on UT shuttle route.
cons: -We had a couple of months of downtime due to the research study being temporarily suspended but we were all contacted promptly as soon as the study was resumed.

job_title: Athletics Department Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Reputation as one of the most recognizable athletics departments in collegiate athletics motivates employees to excel at their jobs. UT has many resources to develop employees.
cons: Policy, procedure, and red tape- change does not happen quickly at UT. Very hierarchical, so salaries at the bottom are minimal and not living wage.

job_title: Senior IT Manager in Austin, TX
pros: Working at UT offers flexibility in some departments, but it depends on the department.  UT also observes several holidays, which is nice around December and January.
cons: Some cons include salary and promotion.  It is very difficult to negotiate once you've been employed in the same position for a while.  It requires title changes which can take a while to move through the approval process.

job_title: Power Systems Technician in Austin, TX
pros: Great place to work.  The benefits are excellent and all the tools and equipment are provided.  The university environment is very stimulating.
cons: Salaries are good but slightly below average.  Parking is a problem.  Driving around campus to job sites can be hazardous because of 50K + students trying to get to classes.

review_title: Two great years spent as a postdoc here, that have proved invaluable to my future career.
pros: Excellent location - Austin is a busy, exciting place to live and work. Excellent benefits - Blue Cross Blue Shield health insurance, which was extremely useful during my time working at the university.
cons: Some parts of the research facilities feel very dated - a decade or so behind the state of similar facilities in other (even less prestigious) academic institutions.

pros: Friendly, hopeful, youthful environment. Excellent benefits -- the long breaks are hard to beat. Stability intrinsic in every position. Good place to have a long career.
cons: Compensation quite low for workload and expected level of education; however, compensation for higher-ups is often ridiculously high. Terrible parking situation. Ability to move and grow within and across departments often difficult. Lots of politics.

review_title: Super convenient, good job for a student.
pros: Tutoring is a lot of fun and a great way to master material.  Very convenient job for a student, especially if you live on or near campus.
cons: Some tutees find it appropriate to show up to a tutoring appointment with only their homework/assignment and no notes, books, etc and expect you to basically just do it for them, even after you emailed and requested they bring course material.

pros: The benefit is awesome and people are very friendly here. UT is pretty generous about the welfare of the employees.
cons: It is a public university with thousands of students and employees. The buildings are always busy with people come and go. The working environment in some old buildings are noisy.

pros: Other staff members are professional and easy to work with. There is always something intellectually engaging going on. Benefits are decent.
cons: Pay for postdoctoral fellows is abysmal (not really UT's fault). No paid maternity leave (also not really UT's fault). Not a lot of perks.

pros: Fast paced research. In the biomedical engineering department, research feels more like an internship. Multiple publication and pattens every year.
cons: It can be difficult to make the load of classes and keeping up with the high demanding tasks. I would recommend only taking 12-13 hours of classes along with your research.

pros: Great benefits and co-workers. Short commute. It's a vibrant educational community and the students are fantastic.
cons: Not a lot of growth. There's always a hiring freeze or a merit pay hold or some other factor going up the Regent or State level. You have to jump around from department to department to have any sort of upward mobility and successes are not financially rewarded.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Availability of good mentoring; flexibility in work hours; good benefits (may vary by department)
cons: Incompetence at the department chair or coordinator level; incompatibility with work as a graduate student; exploitation of international graduate student work force

pros: Great pace and environment. Plenty of advancement opportunities and a great work life balance. The University is a great lifelong place to work.
cons: The pros far outweigh the cons. There are few things to complain about, but the pay isn't super competitive with private companies.

review_title: Working for the university is an overall good experience.
job_title: Senior Media Support Technician in Austin, TX
pros: The university provides a stable, enjoyable place to work. There is a good sense of community as well as a strong support system for employees.
cons: Having to pay just for the chance to park at work is absurd. Salaries are dependent on the legislature so pay is unlikely to go up unless you are faculty or in the upper level of administration.

review_title: If you are looking for an IT job, don't bother looking here!
job_title: Desktop Support Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: Great benefits, good time off, low stress, and flexible schedule.
cons: Horrible pay, no opportunity for advancement, poor morale, constantly changing management, no recognition for good work, favoritism by management, dealing with the ridiculous politics, no transparency and high turnover rate.

pros: Great clients. Great coworkers. Good facilities and atmosphere. Convenient to students- it's easy to drop in before or after class.
cons: Lower pay than other gyms. Sometimes very crowded in Gregory. You probably cannot make a career out of this, but it's good enough for a student.

pros:
-Flexible
-Laid back environment
-Cool People 

Basically, you can find practically anything you want at the University of Texas. With its size it needs people in all sorts of areas.
cons:
No benefits for part time workers
Work can be boring
Pay isn't great (at least for my part-time job)

I must emphasize that I am speaking simply for my position.

pros: I much enjoyed working in an atmosphere of people of all ages who were intelligent and seeking information on a constant basis, and I met some of the best people of my life while I worked and went to school.
cons: The only con of this job, which does not take 20 words to say, the absolute deplorable pay rate for work study students, especially when operating the 11th largest library in the US.

pros: Able to leave on time, campus shuts down for 2 weeks in December and days off don't count against PTO.  Good retirement pension.
cons: People are mean, and not helpful.  Old working environment for old departments.  No budget for extra food or drink for school events.  Hours not flexible and low pay

pros: Surrounded by brilliant people. My manager is highly capable, thoughtful, understanding, and a true leader. Benefits are amazing--great health insurance, staff education benefit, and even in a fairly low-level position I have a desk with a view.
cons: Pay is low. The little things you get used to in a corporate office--coffee machines, etc--are not guaranteed.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
Most graduate teaching assistants' receive a scholarship that covers their entire tuition. 
Excellent teaching/grading/tutoring experience.
cons:
Lack of consistency semester-to-semester. Sometimes the University cuts positions without warning, leaving graduate students high and dry and having to cover the cost of tuition on their own.

Pay does not even cover the cost of living in Austin--$10,000/year is not enough when the cost of apartments are typically $1000 at the absolute least for a studio apartment.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The reputation of the university is great, the staff is high quality and knowledgeable, and a variety of interesting research opportunities are available.
cons: The university system is so large, it is easy to slip through the cracks.  There can sometimes be a lack of direction from supervisors.

review_title: Great job if that's what you like to do
pros: 5-9pm shifts which work well for students, easy going atmosphere, good motivation, high energy team, fun job, get to have conversations with alumni
cons: 4 hours on the phone in the same chair is a long time, most people hate that you're calling (at least in the beginning), it's just not fun to call people and ask for money

pros: This job provided a good job experience and I had a good time and the pay was above average. The people are friendly and I was able to have a good time. They have flexible hours as well. Ruined clothes
cons: This job certainly had cons. I was constantly rushed and overworked. My supervisor was highly demanding and was very strict. I liked it more than I disliked it.

review_title: Great benefits, laid back atmosphere, not great opportunities for growth
job_title: Graduate Program Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: good insurance, great vacation and sick leave, laid back, excellent retirement plan, more secure and stable than private industry
cons: not a lot of room for growth, salaries are on the low side, bureaucracy sometimes protects and sometimes restricts, politics

pros: Assistant Instructors at UT are given good experience with teaching autonomously as instructor of record -- at least in my experience I had considerable liberty.
cons: UT has not made great strides in improving the salaries of graduate student employees. Grad students are never paid well but a graduate stipend from UT doesn't cover even minimal cost of living anymore.

review_title: Part time Student position as a Tutor
pros: Flexible schedules. Bosses are very supportive. I get to set my own hours, and the job pays very well for a student position.
cons: There are limitations for advancement, since all tutors are treated equally regardless of tenure. Many of the students expect you to do their homework rather than learn the material

review_title: UT from a Chem. Grad. Student's Perspective
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Tier 1 research university affords excellent, innovative research opportunities and facilities.
cons: Compared to my small undergraduate college, UT can be a bit overwhelming and impersonal at times. Grad. school work/life balance is notoriously bad, regardless of institution.

pros: Got to work from home. Was given feedback on what was and wasn't working. Overall pretty convenient and non-taxing for a student.
cons: Well, it can get a bit tiresome after a while. Also your mileage may vary depending on which prof is assigned to you.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Develop the research skills while get paid. Good experience to solve the new problems and explore the technology and science.
cons: The workload at graduate school is usually very much. You need to learn to manage your time. Balance your coursework and the research work.

pros: Easy job, once you get the hang of it. The job is quite repetitive, and the only variation is when you meet different customers.
