cons: The job gets boring after a few months of working there. The management is also quite confusing and not consistent when they assign shifts.

pros: Overall OK company to work. Good health benefits.
cons: It is a slow-moving huge bureaucratic machine. Everything requires paperwork, changes are very slow. Huge disparity in the salaries of higher-ups and regular employees. Management often makes grand pronouncements but the reality is much more mundane. A lot of achievements are on paper. Low chances for promotion. High turnover within departments. Parking horrible and expensive.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
Good compensation/ benefits
Great location, Austin is an awesome town, with so much to do. It has something for everyone.
cons:
Too much bureaucracy
Why do I have register as an employee EVERY semester?
No quality control to ensure graduate students are treated fairly.

review_title: There is never a dull moment here.
job_title: Director of Career Services in Austin, TX
pros: This is a top tier institution in an awesome city.  The pay is better than many other colleges including ritzy private schools.  You are often given a lot of autonomy because everyone is maxed out and does not have time to micro-manage.
cons: The students never leave so there is always demand for your time even in the summer.  The vacation time sucks.

pros: In addition to friendly Co-workers, the atmosphere in the Texas Union was of high quality. Friendly supervisor, as well as being able to work well with other departments.
cons: Hours can range variously. As various tasks tend to pile on, the job gets stressful for only a few minutes.

review_title: Mostly what you would expect from a state institution
pros: Nice resources available to everyone...libraries, museums, etc on campus.  Lively environment.  Usually a lot going on, including free events that are educational or of interest.
cons: Things operate very slowly.  Lots of rules that seem oriented towards student-age people, but apply to everyone at the school, including staff.  Many folks act like they work for the state (which, indeed, they do).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Large variety of research options, tons of interesting / nice people.
cons: the research I ended up doing may turn out to lack practical significance, and no one warned me of this in advance.  This isn't a huge issue if you are looking for an exercise in complexity to get an academic career started launched, but if you want to go to industry, it can be a problem.

review_title: Great place to learn how to do research!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
-Congregation of Highly competent, dynamic and diverse researchers many of which dominate the field they are in
-Quite a bit chances of interdisciplinary research to solve cutting edge problems
-Some of the excellent teachers I have seen
cons:
-Austin is too hot in summer...
-Big departments and therefore high competition could be overwhelming for some, but it's a blessing in disguise as per my thinking...

review_title: Teaching Assistant- in the college of natural sciences
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: You will meet some of the friendliest people in your life. My instructor with whom I work is very supportive. She eventually became my mentor. The department that I worked for was small, but still, the experience was incredible.
cons: Not too many downsides. I was working more hours than I was supposed to. Also, it was difficult getting  a day off from work.

pros: I worked with a great team!  My coworkers were extremely supportive of one another.
cons: For such a "rich" university, salaries are not too great. Additionally, there is a lot of bureaucracy to get any "new" changes.

pros: The university offers many great benefits including health insurance, retirement and professional development. It is also a beautiful place to work with lots going on.
cons: There is a lot of burocracy at the university. There are lots of yearly or biannual training modules that seem excessive.

pros: Have plenty of sources for research and study, the students here are brilliant, it is fun to teach them. Also there are a lot of nice Professors
cons: Not much, maybe one is that some labs/classrooms have really old equipment and definitely need some funding to refurnish.

review_title: Student technician, center for teaching and learning
pros: Great experience while you are still studying as a student. My department was flexible with hours and managing responsibility. Good job
cons: Smaller group, you must learn to be independent. I needed to intern the summer before to be eligible for the position

pros: There is a lot of flexibility. I was only assigned to four hours a week of class time, three hours of office hours, and one hour a week of tutoring. Unfortunately (for the students, fortunately for us), all homework was submitted and graded through Quest, an automated homework platform.
cons: Very little training was provided. You will have to be creative and come up with lesson plans on your own.

review_title: The University Unions are a great place to work
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: I enjoyed working with the executive management team on a UTemp assignment.
cons: Parking is impossible so the bus is a must, which can be annoying if you have to make a transfer, which I had to

review_title: A really good experience however limited pay raises.
pros: Great benefits and unlimited sources of library materials.  Knowledgeable staff. Diverse workforce.  The campus has a energy from the students.
cons:
Too big.
All about who you know before you can be promoted.
Limited opportunity to advance.
Limited opportunity to increase salary.

review_title: I've been working at one of the departments at the Law schools and have absolutely loved working here.
pros:
Flexible Schedules and a stress free work environment.
Free lunch at least half the semester due to different activities and events.
Super cordial
cons:
Wage rates aren't the best
Its far from the rest of the campus
O's is the only place to eat

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Great access to wonderful minds and all the flexibility that you expect in an academic environment.
cons: Pay for grad students is still $2-3k below national average but they're working on it with a $1k raise last year.

pros: Employee benefits are really good as far as health insurance, free counseling, access and discounts for events
cons: Strict hourly pay, time keeping has to be meticulous. Do not get spring break or summers off. The erratic cycle of the school year going from very slow to very busy every 6 weeks.

pros: Benefits are bar none; most areas provide flexibility. Beautiful campus, great holiday schedule. they have good options for alternative transportation if you live nearby.
cons: cramming 50,000 daily faculty, staff, students and visitors into less than 15,000 parking spaces. traffic getting to campus is horrible. many positions' pay is below market level, but the insurance benefits sort of makes up for that. sort of.

pros: The university is incredibly diverse. Our students are fantastic and make all the extra effort feel worthwhile. You will meet some of the most creative, intelligent colleagues of your career here.
cons: Like any state institution, UT has quite a few employees who are counting down to retirement. It can be de-motivating to be on a team or in a department with staff who only care about the paycheck and benefits.

pros: The researchers are passionate about their fields and work intensively to make new discoveries. They are understanding about their own processes and the limitations an employee might face.
cons: The focus really is all about the research. If you are not devoted to putting in the hours and getting results (which you then present to your peers and team leads), you may not find a comfortable niche.

job_title: Student Mechanical Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Great Mechanical Engineering program and great school overall. Plenty of opportunities on and around campus for social and academic purposes.
cons: It's a big city with a lot of people. All the hot spots to hike around Austin are usually really packed, and same thing with recreational sports like at Clark field and Gregory gym. Sometimes it's hard to get into a game with so many people.

review_title: Flexible and good for a student
job_title: Assistant to Special Events Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: Very flexible hours, decent pay for the work that you do, the job is not stressful and everyone at the school is friendly enough.
cons: A lot of turnover. This means your often working with unexperienced people. Many of them cannot do the necessary lifting.

pros: Challenging, interesting work at a fast pace; plenty of vacation time (the winter university holidays can be anywhere from one to two weeks in addition to your personal time).
cons: Not all departments offer flexible hours, and the pay is not the greatest. Benefits are reasonable, but not stellar.

review_title: Agood place to start your career
pros:
1. Good faculty and staff. They can provide a lot of guidance during your work.
2. Good equipments for research. Most of state-of-art equipments are available on campus, although they are frequently down.
3. Good work/life balance.
cons:
1. Need a better gym at Pickle Research Campus.
2. Need to handle administrative affairs more effectively.
3. Need to have more professionals to keep the equipments in healthy condition.

review_title: I was a teacher's assistant in freshman chemistry lecture. The workload was lower than I ever thought.
pros: You will get to know how a class is prepared and can build an intimate connection with a lecturer, and this is the most important thing that you will need.
cons: There are no cons I can think of. You can probably work in a worse situation if you get a hard professor.

pros: Wide freedom of topics to research and teach.  Talented colleagues.  Many extraordinary students.
cons: Serious salary compression problem at this university.  In the College of Liberal Arts policies change often and are inconsistently applied.  Significant disparities in salary -- not connected to talent, visibility, scholarly reputation or impact.  Workloads are also unequal reinforcing the problem of unequal compensation.

pros: The school and place are very nice, with excellence professors/teachers and people there. Anyway, a very nice memory for me.
cons: I do not like the place in Austin after I came to CA now. It's much less people to interacted with them.

review_title: The Jackson School of Geosciences is HUGE but has great resources and collaboration potenital if you seek it out!
job_title: Jackson Distinguished Postdoctoral Fellow in Austin, TX
pros: Cutting edge science across very broad disciplines and incredible resources.
cons: Only con would be it is so big that it is hard to know anybody and you really need to seek people out if you want their time. As long as you take the initiative then it is great.

pros: Get to work in a dynamic research environment with many top people. Flexible work hours (as long as you get the work done and you show up for meetings, no one cares where you work).
cons: If you're not tenured or on a "funding expected to continue" position, one has to work from short term contract to short term contract.

pros: Employers at UT are very flexible with student schedules.  Working in the graphics lab gives a great opportunity to grow.
cons: Working with clients that are students can be frustrating.  Sometimes they aren't very organized or prompt to communicate with you.

pros: I worked as a teaching assistant while in graduate school, they paid my tuition pretty much in full, plus provided salary and full benefits. Amazing set up for not a lot of work, highly recommend going the teaching route if you go to school here.
cons: Really don't have anything bad to say, a lot of work at grading time but that's to be expected.

pros:
- My department places its graduates reasonably well within its field
- In Austin
- This job allows me to eat while I pursue my PhD
- I have an office (shared)
cons:
- Not all the placements are so great
- In Austin
- Pay is lower than for graduate student teaching assistants at most other schools
- Workload varies a lot by semester, depending on assignment

pros: Interesting government projects, flexible hours, friendly management.  Access to University resources and competent technical staff.  Director is one of kind, very friendly and knowledgeable.  The staff are well versed and broad.
cons: Difficult to grow.  Flat organizational structure.  Funded by soft-money, so when funding ends, so can the job.

pros: great healthcare benefits, working with students is great, state employment
cons: very competitive to move around within the campus, staff is over worked and under paid, faculty do not respect staff positions, a lot of politics and bureaucratic drama

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: This job has been a great learning experience for the transition between undergraduate and graduate research. I have been working with my group for almost a year, mostly as a student and have learned a lot as well as made good connections in the academic world.
cons: Entry level research positions are paid decently compared to most entry level jobs but low compared to most science positions.

pros: Flexible course choice and good teacher and students. The research is also great here especially engineering.
cons: The food here is not good enough, and the campus is not large enough. Besides, the number of students here is quite large.

pros: It's one of the best schools in US.. pretty big .. good environment and a place to learn new stuff a lot.
cons: My salary was not that good.. The project that i was working on was not funded.. so a kind of hard to find the way to go

review_title: University always has more freedom than industry
pros: Flexible working time. No much pressure. Depending on your bosses much. One can wander around the campus to attend various seminars, audit classes and talk with other researchers.
cons: Varies very much from department to department . Depending much on your bosses again. Overall, University of Texas is not very top university. There are indeed something less than Berkeley, MIT etc.

review_title: Lots of burnt orange tape, but great autonomy.
pros: The autonomy and flexibility I have in my current role is unbelievable. I am able to use my creativity and intuition to develop structures and programs that benefit students, which is what I am passionate about.
cons: Like any other large university, there is a lot of bureaucracy, politics, and big egos.

pros: Worked with facilities and operations. Always something new and different. Get to work in some of the best facilities of any university.
cons: Very hectic schedule. Like most government jobs constrained by purchasing rules and bureaucracy, though because it's such a money maker not as bad as other university departments.

pros: The people are great. The benefits are great, at least that's what I hear. I worked as a student associate at one of the colleges and it was a great experience! Great work off. Whenever there is inclement weather and the school shuts down,  so does the office.
cons: Sometimes it can be busy, but most of the time it is do-able.

job_title: IT Business Analyst in Austin, TX
pros:
People are nice
(Trying to) work in agile
Christmas vacation 
IT gets one remote day a week 
Hard to get fired
cons: In the Libraries there is no motivation for creating innovative user-centered products- the mentality is lets just go with open source products almost out of the box and launch. Don’t come here if you’re looking for exciting, fast-paced, challenging projects in the UX space.

review_title: Great students, confusing career path for teaching professors
pros: Great students, lots of continuing education resources, lots of control over course content. Good benefits.
cons: Short contracts, confusing job path, typical academic politics and disregard for teaching at a research university. Title IX compliance problematic.

review_title: work environment varies based on department
pros: good benefits, slower-pace work environment, low stress
cons: large, bureaucratic, and inefficient; excessive tiered rules and regulations (at university, state, and federal levels) preventing many activities; hard  to implement new ideas and initiatives; many employees are disengaged.

job_title: Research Scientist Associate IV in Austin, TX
pros: Great place to work and great life experience at Austin. State-of-the-arts research in all aspects of engineering field is being done here.
cons: This is a soft money position. Salary is tied closely to your research project. So sometimes every two or three years, you need to worry about funding issues. Besides, salary raise is limited due to state wide financial situation.

pros: I was able to work with the University as part of my work-study financial aid reward for a few years. The staff was always understanding about the pressure from my academic life and they were always willing to accommodate me.
cons: In my position I was just an hourly wage earner and although I earned more than minimum wage I didn't get any benefits.

pros: It's very flexible. You can either choose to work in appointment tutoring (AT) only or do both AT and drop in tutoring. You can set your hours and work as many hours as you like. The only requirement is that you post at least 10 hours of availability each week.
cons: The only challenge is sometimes not being able to answer a student's question.

review_title: Great Part-Time Job as a Student
pros: The job is fairly simple and they only hire you if you are an expert in the subject you tutor.  It helps if you have already taken the courses or are currently taking related courses because it serves as a great way to review the material and keep it fresh in your head.
cons: Variable work hours, hourly pay.

job_title: Chemical Stockroom Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: This is good for a little experience in maintenance in the lab and thinking up some creative solutions to undergraduates problems. You can also get the chance to learn some things about the instrumentation and common problems associated with them.
cons: A lot of tedious tasks since every task requires you to times it by 120 for each student. Other than that pretty good.

review_title: Good place to work but salary is not satisfactory compared to the expense of housing
pros: A world-class university with good facilities and talented students. There are a lot of room for professional development. Support from the development was strong.
cons: Salary is not satisfactory compared to the expense of housing. The price of housing has been soaring in the past decade because of the increasing job opportunities.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Lots of hands-on experience in a subject matter that you find interesting to you and helpful to the world.
cons: Some professors and grad students allow very little room for input from undergraduates; you may be reduced to doing menial lab work.

pros: The opportunity to conduct independent research pursuing my own questions was interesting. I like being able to set my own schedule for the most part.
cons: The low pay is terrible. The 60+ hour weeks for low pay is even worse. Doing this for 5+ years is the worst.

pros: Great leadership experience, gain valuable relationships with your facilitator and with the students in your FIG
cons: Time commitment - you do have to plan out each seminar class and have a back up plan in case one of your lesson plans happens to fall through

review_title: Great benefits, Experience depends on manager
pros:
- Great benefits
- Organization with important mission
- Access to incredible wealth of knowledge
- Easy to build a large network
cons:
- Non-competative salaries, no regular increases
- Politics are sometimes tedious
- Inconsistent management practices across campus means your mileage may vary

pros: It's a great university, with a beautiful campus and great amenities (a nice gym, for instance) and in an amazing city! It's a very youthful environment, and students are high level.  The benefits fit my life really well.
cons: It's a temporary contract, which is not ideal. Also, some of the institutes have very old professors, which create an out of date working environment.

pros: Good time off during the holidays, you know when to anticipate the busy time of year and a vibrant place to work. Intellectual atmosphere, access to conferences and higher educational events. People are generally nice, just limited growth opportunities.
cons: Parking, pay, and the always present glass ceiling.

pros: Creative environment among students in eclectic campus setting.
cons: Employees with little or no talent, but years of service take precedence.  Young talent gets used and discarded with no recourse.

pros:
-Access to education/programmatic opportunities
-Accessibility to transit (free bus transit)
-The org is intending on creating a more inclusive culture across departments/schools/centers
cons:
-Salary is low in response to the cost of living or Austin 
-Very hierarchical org and cubicle farms. Very different than the funky start ups, which Austin is known for. 
-Retirement plan sucks (TRS with a long vesting period). Benefits could improve

review_title: Excellent place to work while going to school
pros:
Decent pay for the amount of work you have to put in.
You tend to work with fellow students.
The supervisors are great.
Lots of downtime during work, giving you time to study.
You're allowed to bring things to occupy your time (e.g. laptop, book, etc.)
cons:
Hours can be considered long, especially during football season.
You always work outside.
Assignments can be inconsistent.

pros: Good students/collaborators, opportunity to work hard and be productive, Interesting projects, potential for high visibility, conference travel, some user facilities are excellent
cons: Chem dept. is a toxic mess right now, anything in the CNT/TMI/FNT nano area is a territorial mess due to its proximity to chemistry, lack of professional development opportunities, you are expected to be a paper mill and not much else.

pros: They understand that you are a full time student and work around your schedule. They let you use what you have learned in school to be creative with the work given. They are very open  to suggestions and treat you like a colleague.
cons: Not very challenging of a job. They could do a lot more with the talent they are given.

pros: Health insurance, vacation, sick time is outstanding.
cons: Salary is extremely low + university does not protect and care for staff as much as they do faculty and students.

review_title: Good benefits, but no place for growth
pros: Flexible hours, work-life balance, great benefits, friendly staff
cons: You have to pay for parking; managers are too caught up on big picture stuff that they don't recognize the lower-level folks doing all the work; too much work load and not enough personnel; being stretch too thin

review_title: Working for the University of Texas at Austin has been a consistent place of employment.
pros: Staff is very flexible with your school schedule. I was able to make my own work schedule and alter it as needed. Supervisors are appreciative of student workers and take the time to say thank you.
cons: There are many inefficiencies within the university (communication, data systems, budgeting, etc.).

review_title: They treat their TAs better than most!
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
(This is for the Computer Science Department)

Given cost of living, their TA salaries are pretty good, and their medical benefits are awesome.  MOST professors are very reasonable in their expectations of their graduate students, too.
cons: Some professors can make very unreasonable demands, but the department can definitely help you out if that is a problem.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Plenty of opportunities to develop skills in a laboratory or engineering setting. Some of the best professors in the country as well as competent grad students to work with.
cons: Often unpaid, opportunities are not always advertised, so you must do some networking to find out who is looking for undergraduates.

pros: Friendly co-workers, benefits are great, overtime opportunities
cons: Very high-pace, high customer traffic, unorganized management, must keep your cool, very demanding

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Good compensation for the right admin/clerical positions. Great benefits. Wonderful interactions with students. Energetic atmosphere on campus with new and exciting things happening each season.
cons: Hard to get off clerical track and advance into higher paying non-clerical roles.  Some offices stuck in the way they've always done things. Not always supportive in developing employees to advance and move up.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: UT Austin is a great place.  The people are nice and the department I worked in was wonderful.
cons: Depending on how you get paid as a graduate student, you might or might now have health insurance paid for by your lab.

pros: Everyone is friendly and ready to work with you. I worked in a small office as a research assistant/teaching assistant part-time. Everyone was happy to mentor me and find my first real job.
cons: If you allow people to work you to death, they will. This can happen in any environment, though. Overall, no big complaints!

pros: The hours and benefits are amazing, the work can be rewarding
cons: As an SDA I feel I am not living up to my title at times, very little challenge and the pay is not so bueno (Expected from a public university though)

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Good extra pay while getting my Masters degree at the school.  Really nice to teach college level musicians.  Easy to work with current jazz studies faculty.  Must be a current graduate student to receive this job.
cons: Nothing negative to report.  It is a great part time job.

pros: Great university with top notch students and excellent resources for its students to grow and succeed! Staff is probably amongst the best in the US!
cons: Like most large institutions, it's got it's share of bureaucracy that can make it tough to move quickly on things, but the university is doing a great job keeping at pace or ahead of the industry.

review_title: Quality instruction, tuition waived, overall good experience
pros: Tuition waived with GRA/TA position, quality instruction from the engineering department, state of the art research.
cons: Grad school consumes your life. In between attending classes, teaching as a TA, and doing research on the side, you'll find yourself in very stressful situations. Yet you are paid basically minimum wage.

pros: Good education, great city, great employment opportunities when you graduate.
cons: Stipend is not enough to rent an apartment without multiple roommates or co-signer who makes 5x the rent. Professors are somewhat out of touch with cost of living in Austin.

review_title: Resources available for learning and research
pros: At the University of Texas, you can be student while working as proctor at the computer lab, or work as research assistant and get paid
cons: You just have to ask and you will get it. In term of courses, you may have to do thing on your own because professor are more busy with their researches

job_title: Information Technology Coordinator II in Austin, TX
pros:
- The department I worked in was a very close knit group.
- Everyone got along very well.
- People I interacted with were top notch.
- Used updated technology.
cons:
- Minimal pay increases due to budgets.
- Fairly slow moving when it comes to policies being changed.
- Parking is very difficult to find.

review_title: While welcoming of new ideas, the University is mired in a political system that is toxic for higher education.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Top Tier Research, focused on shared governance
cons: Employing enough people resistant to change in a time where academia MUST adapt

review_title: The work is very exciting to me and my coworkers also incline me to do my job better each time.
pros: Tasks are challenging but doable at the same time and co-workers are feasible to interact with.
cons: When no clients call, the work load decreases, therefore less productivity.

pros: Best work-life balance while offering extraordinary opportunities to contribute to the betterment of the world.  "What starts here changes the world" sounds bold, and UT-Austin delivers.  Engaging students, faculty who really cares, research that touches a broad range of important topics.  Excellent institution.
cons: Not enough employment opportunities, would love to work there again!

review_title: The eyes of Texas are upon you!
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The Unversity of Texas is an amazing place to work. I have made invaluable connections and had the opportunity to do work in a field I was passionate about.
cons: Its a huge school so it can take some time to find your place, but once you do you'll love it.

job_title: Grants and Contracts Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: I worked with two supervisors who really supported my career growth, and had a wonderful experience. Benefits are of course great.
cons: Constant budget cuts and pressure from the state legislature and system can create a challenging political environment.

job_title: Senior Web Developer in Austin, TX
pros: Great people, nice campus, great benefits, stable employment and retirement plans.
cons: Blatant sexism (towards women), nepotism, below-market salaries for most workers, upper management paid too much. Depending on the office you work for, you could end up a dilapidated office space.

review_title: Easy Job which paid for my tuition
pros:
-Academic Setting
-Easy going possessors usually
cons: -Unreliable continuation of position as position is dependent on department funding

job_title: Senior Administrative Associate in Austin, TX
pros: pension, free access to CapMetro bus and train, free tuition for 1 class per semester, health insurance
cons: pay for parking, raises are small and sometimes zero due to state legislature, almost have to know someone to post for job

pros: Great health insurance, collaborative environment, independence on projects and many on-site resources at the University for intellectual growth and professional development
cons: Low pay for the difficulty of work and level of expertise needed, many roles to play with little training

pros: Great academic environment being around students.  Usually some flexibility with work hours to help with kids.
cons: Campus leadership doesn't have their act together.  This causes uncertainty as a staff member, changes come often and unexpectedly and don't always make sense.  Lots of government bureaucracy frustration, corrosive culture in many staff areas due to poor management.  Many managers, directors, AVPs, assistant deans express similar frustrations with leadership.

review_title: Great place to be a PhD student
pros: I love it here. Great people, great support from the math department, I never had second thoughts about comming here.
cons: I have heard the salaries are lower than in most other Universities in the united states.

review_title: Tons of resources for your success but you have to leverage them. Sink or swim.
job_title: Director of Development in Austin, TX
pros: Wealth of resources, human and otherwise. Collaborative culture. Positive energy and enthusiasm. As a fundraiser, if you produce, you’re rewarded.
cons: Easy to get lost in the mix. If your supervisor doesn’t truly care about your professional development you will not have a great experience.

review_title: Good, relaxed environment. Constant management turnover.
pros:
Good, relaxed job. 
Good benefits( free housing) in relation to time commitment. 
Flexible working hours built around your schedule.
Good co-workers most of the time.
cons:
Red tape.
Constant turnover at mid- upper management positions due to hall coordinators leaving to pursue PHDs.
Experience heavily dependent on manager.

pros: no work life balance. beautiful clean campus in a great city
cons:
teach yourself. the professors don't care about you and they don't care to each
based on a plus minus grading system :(

pros: Great place to work. Relaxed atmosphere. Best benefits I can imagine are available, discounted gym membership and ability to work out during lunch.
cons: I think the only thing that could be a negative is the pay. It's not bad, but nothing to write home about but the other benefits FAR outweigh the economic portion of the job.

pros: Great benefits for grad students who are 20 hours. Work is directly related to areas of study. Easy process to get hired. Professors have really interesting projects.
cons: No grad position is the same which means you'll have to hope the right kind of project comes along when you are looking.

pros: Friendly co-workers, supportive supervisors. Free rent for a two bedroom apartment plus utilities are part of your compensation. Great experience with in diverse international population.
cons: You are expected to be available for work anytime. Very difficult to balance demands of work, school, family. Giving violations to your neighbors makes them not like you.

pros: Pay rate and hours are great for someone seeking a part-time job to supplement there income.
cons: Poor management, and there are plenty of angry customers. You need to be patient for this job.

review_title: Working at the university writing center is the best college job
pros:
Flexible timing
Social setting
Pays well
Great bosses
Meet people while working
Your own writing improves
Time flies by while at work
cons: College students can be overwhelming to work with, and editing without being directive can be difficult. Overall great place to work at.

pros: Great benefits, working in Downtown Austin is awesome, excellent job security.
cons: An employee can effect little change, even when inefficiencies are found.  Low base salaries. It is difficult to move up within the organization. Little appreciation is shown to employees.

review_title: UT Austin, the good and the bad
pros: Benefits,  working conditions, access to  university facilities
cons: Political, many of the employees are well educated but have never worked outside the UT system. University software programs, many are outdated, new software not user-friendly. Nepotism, bias against those without advanced degrees.

pros: So much experience is to be gained by working here as a student, there is a good deal of flexibility and you are competing with other professionals as a student.
cons: Lots of products to sell, and the company can be very slow moving at times

review_title: UT Austin is a great place to work
pros: UT Austin provides a great academic environment and good infrastructure to carry out research.
cons: Not much that I can think of. I would be nitpicking if I mentioned that it does not have much of a campus since it is in the heart of the city.

pros: It varies by department, but my assistanships the DRW pays well and is very flexible, particularly for people working at the UWC. The UWC is probably the best on-campus job one can get.
cons: You cannot work over a certain number of hours.

review_title: Graduate Assistant Web developer and Programmer
job_title: Graduate Assistant Web Developer in Austin, TX
pros: Flexible time schedule, acceptable workload, pleasant working environment, learn skills at job system
cons: Medium salary, not much promotion potential, it is good for some one desire a stable working status

pros: The benefits are great, and the full time schedule still gives you time to pursue other money making opportunities.
cons: You'll need those other money making opportunities because the pay is way below what they should be paying someone with a Ph.D. Even if you make it to Senior Lecturer, the pay does not go up considerably.

pros: Can practice some oral speaking skills. Some students are nice and interesting to work with.
cons:
-Coordinator just makes sure he has all vacant positions filled. No respect to individual's specialty or interest
-Assignments are not equal in terms of time. Two labs with different work loads are usually considered equivalent on the coordinator's worksheet, resulting some people having over occupied schedule while some other people have nothing to do.
-No real evaluation of TA's perfermance. You can make every student hates you yet still earn the same money next year.

review_title: Excellent university with great work/life balance
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Big university with top-tier professors, strong ties with industry, lots of opportunities. Austin is still very affordable for students as compared to other places.
cons: Diversity and international visibility could be better, UT lags behind other top-tier universities in these criteria.

review_title: One of the best places I’ve ever worked!!!
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Port Aransas, TX
pros: Professional people, vacation & time off, good insurance, retirement plan, advancement opportunities.  Plus, a lot of additional perks.  Ex: discounted tickets to events on campus.
